options: "a: You cannot cross the line to pass., b: You may cross the line to pass and change lanes., c: You may only cross the line to change lanes if you are in the left lane."
note: "A broken white line indicates that you may cross the line to pass or change lanes."

question: If you drive faster than other vehicles on a road with one lane moving in each direction and continually pass the other cars, you will:
options: "a: Get you to your destination much more quickly and safely., b: Increase your chances of an collision., c: Help prevent traffic congestion."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'Staying in one lane as much as possible. Do not weave in and out of traffic. Last minute lane or direction changes may increase the risk of collisions.' (page 14)"

question: Roads with double solid yellow line markings down the center indicate that passing is:
options: "a: Allowed from both directions., b: Allowed only from your direction of travel., c: Not allowed from either direction."
note: "Double solid yellow lines indicate a lane barrier between a regular use and a preferential use lane, such as a carpool (HOV) lane. You may also see double solid white lines in or near freeway on and off ramps. Never change lanes over double solid white lines. Wait until you see a single broken white line. "

question: When changing lanes, you should never:
options: "a: Cross the centerline in an intersection., b: Check your blind spots by looking over your left or right shoulder., c: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 14: 'Never change lanes over double solid white lines. Wait until you see a single broken white line.'"

question: When changing lanes:
options: "a: Check your side mirror and look over your shoulder to make sure the lane is clear., b: Check the inside rearview mirror., c: Slow down."
note: "The DMV handbook states that before changing lanes, you should 'Check your mirrors. Check traffic behind and beside you. Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move to make sure the lane is clear.'"

question: When driving on a multilane street with two-way traffic:
options: "a: Drive alongside other vehicles so the drivers can see you., b: You should drive ahead of or behind the other vehicles., c: It is safest to drive in the lane next to the centerline."
note: "The DMV handbook states that on a multilane road with two-way traffic, 'Use the left lane to pass or turn left.' and 'Use the right lane to enter or exit traffic or when you enter the road from a curb or shoulder.'"

question: When you want to change lanes, you should never:
options: "a: Move into another lane while within an intersection., b: Check your blind spot by looking over your shoulder., c: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Once you start moving through an intersection, keep going. If you start to make a turn, follow through.' (page 14) It is not safe to change lanes within an intersection as other vehicles may be approaching or already in the intersection."

question: Which of the following increases your chances of being in a collision?
options: "a: Looking over your shoulder while making lane changes, b: Continuously changing lanes to pass other vehicles, c: Adjusting your rearview mirror before you start driving"
note: "Continuously changing lanes to pass other vehicles increases the risk of collision.  'Stay in one lane as much as possible. Do not weave in and out of traffic. Last minute lane or direction changes may increase the risk of collisions.'"

question: Which of the following is not a safe driving practice when driving on the interstate?
options: "a: Slower traffic must keep to the right., b: Change lanes without signaling., c: If you miss your exit"
note: "The DMV handbook states 'Stay in one lane as much as possible. Do not weave in and out of traffic. Last minute lane or direction changes may increase the risk of collisions.'  Changing lanes without signaling is not a safe driving practice, and it is not allowed on the interstate."

question: Which of these statements is true about changing lanes?
options: "a: You only need to turn and look over your right shoulder for lane changes to the right or left., b: Look over your right shoulder for a right lane change and your left shoulder for a left lane change., c: Vehicles with two outside mirrors do not have blind spots."
note: "Before changing lanes, you should check your mirrors, check traffic behind and beside you, and then look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move to make sure the lane is clear."

question: While driving on a roadway with a single broken white centerline:
options: "a: You must stay within your lane., b: You may cross the centerline to change lanes., c: You may change lanes only from the left lane."
note: "A broken white line separates traffic lanes on roads with two or more lanes in the same direction.  You may change lanes over a broken white line."

question: You are driving in the far right lane of a four-lane freeway and notice thick broken white lines on the left side of your lane. You are driving in:
options: "a: The carpool lane and must merge into the next lane., b: A special lane for slow-moving vehicles., c: An exit lane."
note: "According to page 14, 'Ending freeway and street lanes are usually marked with large broken lines. If you are driving in a lane marked with broken lines, be prepared to exit the freeway or for the lane to end.'"

question: Carpool lanes are marked with a diamond symbol. To use these lanes during the special hours shown on the signs you must
options: "a: Be driving a van or bus, b: Drive at the speed limit or have your lights on, c: Have the minimum number of passengers shown on the signs."
note: "Carpool lanes are marked with a diamond symbol and the words 'Carpool Lane'. 'To use an HOV lane, one of these must apply: - You have a certain number of people in your vehicle. There will be signs at the on-ramp or along the road to tell you the minimum number of people. Road signs also list the hours when the HOV rules apply.'"

question: Which of the following increases your chances of having a collision?
options: "a: Continuously changing lanes to pass other vehicles, b: Adjusting your rearview mirror before you start driving, c: Looking over your shoulder while making lane changes"
note: "Continuously changing lanes to pass other vehicles is dangerous as it can lead to collisions.  'Stay in one lane as much as possible. Do not weave in and out of traffic. Last minute lane or direction changes may increase the risk of collisions.'"

question: When changing lanes on a freeway, you should:
options: "a: Signal for at least five seconds., b: Slow down before you start to change lanes., c: Assume there is enough space in the next lane for your vehicle"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Signal at least five seconds before you change lanes on a freeway.'"

question: You are driving a slow moving vehicle on a winding two-lane highway. You must pull over when it is safe and let other drivers pass when you are followed by
options: "a: 3 vehicles, b: 4 vehicles, c: 5 or more vehicles"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, on a two-lane road with five or more vehicles behind you, you must use a turnout area or lane to let other vehicles pass when you are driving slowly, where passing is unsafe.  'You must use a turnout area or lane to let other vehicles pass when you are driving slowly on a two-lane road, where passing is unsafe, and there are five or more vehicles following you.'"

question: It is illegal to drive in a bicycle lane unless you are:
options: "a: in need of the space and the bike lane is empty., b: Passing another vehicle, c: Parking (where permitted)"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 17, 'It is illegal to drive in a bicycle lane unless you are: Parking (where permitted). Entering or leaving the road. Turning (within 200 feet of an intersection).'"

question: You may drive a motor vehicle in a bike lane:
options: "a: If you drive more slowly than 15 mph., b: No more than 200 feet before making a right turn., c: Whenever bicyclists are not present."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'It is illegal to drive in a bicycle lane unless you are: Parking (where permitted), Entering or leaving the road, Turning (within 200 feet of an intersection).'"

question: What should you do to make a right turn at an upcoming intersection?
options: "a: Merge into the bicycle lane before making the turn., b: Wait until the bicycle lane ends then make the turn., c: Make the turn from your current lane and do not enter the bicycle lane."
note: "To make a right turn, drive close to the right edge of the road. If a designated right turn lane is available, enter at the opening. You can drive in a bike lane within 200 feet from the turn. Check for bicyclists in your blind spots."

question: You are driving alongside a bicycle lane and want to turn right at a corner. You should signal, look carefully for bike riders, then
options: "a: Merge into the bike lane before turning, b: Make your turn being careful to stay out of the bike lane, c: Speed up and pass any bicycle riders before they get to the corner"
note: "The DMV Handbook states: 'You can drive in a bike lane within 200 feet from the turn. Check for bicyclists in your blind spots.'"

question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
options: "a: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to., b: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn., c: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb."
note: "The DMV handbook states that when turning right, you should drive close to the right edge of the road.  It also states that when turning right from a one-way street onto a one-way street, you should start the turn in the far-right lane.  This means you should wait for the truck or bus to turn before you turn, rather than quickly turning before them or squeezing between them and the curb."

question: To make a right turn at a corner, you:
options: "a: May not enter the bicycle lane., b: Should only merge into the bicycle lane if you stop before turning., c: Must merge into the bicycle lane before turning."
note: "The DMV Handbook states: 'You can drive in a bike lane within 200 feet from the turn. Check for bicyclists in your blind spots.'"

question: When making a right turn from a highway with two lanes traveling in your direction, you may turn from:
options: "a: The lane closest to the center of the road., b: The lane nearest the curb or edge of the roadway., c: Either lane"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, when making a right turn from a highway with two lanes traveling in your direction, you may turn from 'the lane nearest the curb or edge of the roadway'."

question: You are getting ready to make a right turn. You should:
options: "a: Signal and turn immediately., b: Stop before entering the right lane and let all other traffic go first., c: Slow down or stop"
note: "To make a right turn, drive close to the right edge of the road. If a designated right turn lane is available, enter at the opening.  You can drive in a bike lane within 200 feet from the turn. Check for bicyclists in your blind spots. Watch for pedestrians, bicyclists, or motorcyclists between your vehicle and the curb. Start signaling about 100 feet before the turn. Look over your right shoulder and reduce your speed. Stop behind the limit line. A limit line is a wide white line that shows the drivers where to stop before an intersection or crosswalk. If there is no limit line, stop before you enter the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, stop before you enter the intersection.  Look both ways (left-right-left) and turn when it is safe. Complete your turn in the right lane. Do not turn wide into another lane."

question: You want to make a right turn at an upcoming intersection. You should slow down and:
options: "a: Move toward the left side of your lane., b: Avoid driving in the bicycle lane., c: Signal for 100 feet before turning."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 18, 'Start signaling about 100 feet before the turn.'"

question: When you prepare to make a left turn from a one-way road into a one-way road, you must
options: "a: Move into the left lane or to the left side of a single lane, b: Move into the right lane or to the right side of a single lane, c: Move into the right lane or to the left side of a single lane"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'To turn left: Drive close to the center divider or into the left turn lane.' On a one-way street, you should be driving in the far left lane, so to turn left you should remain in that lane."

question: When preparing to make a left turn from a two-way street, you should drive:
options: "a: Near the right-hand side of the road., b: Near the centerline., c: On the left of the centerline."
note: "To make a left turn, you should drive 'close to the center divider or into the left turn lane.'"

question: You enter a designated turn lane to make a left turn at an upcoming intersection. There is oncoming traffic. You should:
options: "a: Move to the left of the center lane., b: Signal before you arrive at the intersection., c: Turn your front wheels to the left to be prepared to turn."
note: "Before making any turns, it is crucial to signal your intention to other drivers. The DMV handbook states, 'Start signaling 100 feet before the turn.'"

question: In which lane should you end your turn when making a right turn?
options: "a: Any lane free of traffic., b: The lane closest to the left edge of the road., c: The lane closest to the right edge of the road."
note: "To make a right turn, you should end your turn in the lane closest to the right edge of the road. 'Do not swing wide into another lane of traffic.'"

question: Where a left turn at an intersection can be started from either of two lanes, a U-turn can be started from
options: "a: Either of the two lanes, b: Only the left lane, c: Any lane that is open"
note: "According to page 20 of the DMV Handbook, 'To make a U-turn, signal and use the left turn lane or far-left lane.'"

question: To make a right turn onto a two-way street from a two-way street, start in the right-hand lane and end in
options: "a: Any lane that is available, b: The left lane, c: The lane closest to the curb"
note: "According to page 20, 'To make a right turn: Drive close to the right edge of the road... Complete your turn in the right lane. Do not turn wide into another lane.'"

question: You may make a left turn on a red light from:
options: "a: One-way street. onto a 2-way street, b: One-way street onto a one-way street., c: Two-way street. onto a one-way street.
note: "You may turn left against a red light when you are turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Make sure there is no sign prohibiting the turn. Yield to other vehicles, pedestrians, or bicyclists who have a green light. Look both ways and turn when it is safe."

question: A U-turn is not permitted:
options: "a: In a parking lot., b: On or near any curve or hill., c: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you cannot make a U-turn 'When you cannot see clearly for 200 feet in each direction.' (Page 20).  Therefore, a U-turn is not permitted on or near any curve or hill."

question: Never make a U-turn:
options: "a: in residential districts., b: at or on a railroad crossing., c: where there isn't a ‘No U-turn’ sign posted."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Never make a U-turn: ... At or on a railroad crossing.'"

question: U-turns in business districts are:
options: "a: Always illegal because they are dangerous., b: Legal whenever oncoming vehicles are not a hazard., c: Legal at intersections"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 20 that U-turns are never legal in business districts. 'Never make a U-turn: ... in business districts (the part of a city or town where most offices and businesses are).'"

question: Which lane must you be in before making a left turn from a one-way street?
options: "a: The lane nearest the left curb., b: The lane nearest the center of the street., c: The lane nearest the right curb."
note: "To make a left turn from a one-way street, you must be in 'the far-left lane' or 'the lane closest to the middle of the street'.  This information is found on page 20."

question: You are driving on a one-way street. You may only turn left onto another one-way street if:
options: "a: You increase your speed before the turn., b: Traffic on the street moves to the right., c: Traffic on the street moves to the left."
note: "You may turn left against a red light when you are turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Make sure there is no sign prohibiting the turn. Yield to other vehicles, pedestrians, or bicyclists who have a green light. Look both ways and turn when it is safe."

question: You may make a left turn on a red light only from a:
options: "a: One-way street onto a two-way street., b: One-way street onto a one-way street., c: Two-way street onto a one-way street."
note: "You may turn left against a red light when you are turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Make sure there is no sign prohibiting the turn. Yield to other vehicles, pedestrians, or bicyclists who have a green light. Look both ways and turn when it is safe."

question: Where should you begin a left turn from a one-way street onto a one-way street?
options: "a: The lane closest to the center of the street., b: The far-left lane., c: You can turn from any lane."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 21, 'Left turn from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Start the turn from the far-left lane.'"

question: To turn left from a multilane one way street onto a one way street. You should start your turn from
options: "a: Any lane as long as it is safe, b: The lane closest to the left curb, c: The lane in the center of the road, d: None of the above"
note: "According to page 21, 'Left turn from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Start the turn from the far-left lane. If there are three or more lanes in your direction of travel, you may end your turn in any lane that is open.'"

question: To turn left from a one-way street onto a one-way street, start from:
options: "a: The lane closest to the left curb., b: The center lane., c: Any lane"
note: "According to page 21, 'To turn left from a one-way street onto a one-way street. Start the turn from the far-left lane.'"

question: To turn left from a one-way street with multiple lanes onto a two-way street, start the turn in:
options: "a: The far left lane., b: Any available lane., c: The lane closest to the middle of the street."
note: "The DMV handbook states that to turn left from a one-way street onto a two-way street, you should start the turn from the far-left lane. This is to reduce the risk of collision."

question: When turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should:
options: "a: Turn into any lane., b: Turn into first lane., c: Turn into second lane."
note: "According to page 21 of the DMV handbook, 'If there are three or more lanes in your direction of travel, you may end your turn in any lane that is open.'"

question: You are merging onto an interstate highway. You should:
options: "a: Select a safe gap and merge into the lane of traffic., b: Merge across two lanes at once., c: Always stop before entering the highway."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'When you enter a highway, you will need to... Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so. Do not stop unless absolutely necessary.'"

question: When you enter a freeway from an on ramp and merge with traffic, you should be driving at
options: "a: The legal speed limit on the freeway, b: About the same speed as the freeway traffic, c: About 10 m.p.h. slower than the freeway speed limit"
note: "The DMV handbook states that when merging onto a highway, 'Be in the proper lane on the on-ramp. - Be at or near the speed of traffic.'"

question: If you are leaving a parking lot, you
options: "a: Must turn either left or right only when it is safe, b: Have the right-of-way, c: Must yield to traffic before re-entering the road"
note: "When entering traffic from a full stop, signal and leave a large enough space to get up to the speed of traffic.  To merge, enter, or exit traffic, you need a space that is:  - Half a block on city streets, which is about 150 feet.  - A full block on the highway, which is about 300 feet."

question: If you have a green light, but traffic is blocking the intersection, you should
options: "a: Enter the intersection and wait until traffic clears, b: Merge into another lane and try to go around the traffic, c: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears"
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway.  'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: A vehicle that enters a road from a driveway
options: "a: Has the right-of-way, b: Must stop and yield the right-of-way to traffic on the roadway and to pedestrians, c: Must yield to traffic approaching from the right while it has the right-of-way over vehicles approaching from the left"
note: "According to the DMV handbook,  'When entering traffic, you must proceed with caution and yield to the traffic already occupying the lanes.' (Page 23) Therefore, a vehicle entering a roadway from a driveway must stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles already on the roadway and to pedestrians."

question: When you are merging onto the freeway, you should be driving
options: "a: at or near the same speed as the traffic on the freeway, b: 5 to 10 mph slower than the traffic on the freeway, c: The posted speed limit for traffic on the freeway"
note: "The DMV handbook states 'Be in the proper lane on the on-ramp. - Be at or near the speed of traffic. - Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so. Do not stop unless absolutely necessary.' "

question: How long before changing lanes on a freeway should you signal?
options: "a: 1-2 seconds, b: 2-4 seconds, c: 3-5 seconds"
note: "The California Driver's Handbook states, 'Signal at least five seconds before you change lanes on a freeway.' This is the same as 'approximately 400 feet'."

question: You are driving on the freeway and need to exit. You should:
options: "a: Use your turn signal and move into the exit lane, b: Exit immediately without signaling, c: Accelerate into the exit lane, d: None of the above"
note: "To exit a highway safely, you should know your exit and be aware of when it is approaching. If you plan to change lanes, do so one at a time. Signal and look over your shoulder to check your blind spots. When in the proper lane, signal five seconds (approximately 400 feet) before you exit."

question: If you miss your exit on the freeway, you should not:
options: "a: Continue on the freeway and find an alternate route to your destination., b: Proceed to the next exit, c: Back up on the road or shoulder."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, page 23,  'If you miss your exit, continue around until you return to your exit.'  Therefore, option 'c' is the incorrect answer."

question: If you want to enter the freeway but you don't see a gap in traffic, you should:
options: "a: Maintain your speed and force the other drivers to create a gap., b: Slow down on the ramp to wait for a gap., c: Stop at the end of the ramp to wait for a gap."
note: "You should 'Slow down on the ramp to wait for a gap.' as stated on page 23 of the DMV Handbook. It says that when entering a highway, you should 'Be at or near the speed of traffic... Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so. Do not stop unless absolutely necessary.'"

question: To enter a gap in highway traffic:
options: "a: Watch only the vehicles behind the gap., b: Check behind you, c: Speed up and let the other vehicles make way."
note: "To merge into a space large enough for your vehicle to safely join the lane, use your mirrors and turn signals. 'Turn your head quickly to look over your shoulder before changing lanes or merging into traffic.'"

question: When entering an interstate highway, you should:
options: "a: Stop, b: Check for cars and reduce your speed to 25 mph before entering the traffic lane., c: Check for cars"
note: "When entering a highway, you will need to: Be in the proper lane on the on-ramp, Be at or near the speed of traffic, Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so. Do not stop unless absolutely necessary."

question: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, you should:
options: "a: Immediately enter the far-right traffic lane on the interstate and speed up to match the flow of traffic., b: Use the shoulder of the main road to get up to the speed of traffic., c: Speed up and enter the interstate only after you have identified a gap in traffic."
note: "The correct answer is 'c: Speed up and enter the interstate only after you have identified a gap in traffic.'. The DMV handbook states, 'When you enter a highway, you will need to...Be at or near the speed of traffic...Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so. Do not stop unless absolutely necessary.'"

question: When entering the interstate, check for a gap in traffic in the nearest lane, adjust your speed to match traffic, signal, and:
options: "a: Expect traffic to allow you to proceed into the lane, b: Merge carefully into the gap., c: Wait for the lane to clear before merging."
note: "The DMV handbook states that when entering a highway, you should 'Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so. Do not stop unless absolutely necessary.' The correct answer is to 'Merge carefully into the gap.' "

question: When entering traffic after being parked at a curb, you:
options: "a: Should drive more slowly than other traffic for 200 feet., b: Should wait for a large enough gap to get up to the speed of traffic., c: Should wait for the first two vehicles to pass"
note: "The DMV handbook states that when entering traffic from a full stop, signal and leave a large enough space to get up to the speed of traffic."

question: You are entering a freeway. Check traffic on the freeway by:
options: "a: Using your rearview and side mirrors., b: Using your rearview mirror., c: Using your side mirror and looking over your shoulder."
note: "Before you enter a highway, you will need to...Merge into highway traffic when safe to do so. Do not stop unless absolutely necessary.  Use your mirrors and turn signals.  Turn your head quickly to look over your shoulder before changing lanes or merging into traffic."

question: You are preparing to exit the interstate. When should you start reducing your speed?
options: "a: About halfway through the deceleration lane., b: As you approach the deceleration lane., c: Immediately upon entering the deceleration lane."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'When in the proper lane, signal five seconds (approximately 400 feet) before you exit.' This indicates that you should start reducing your speed as you approach the deceleration lane, allowing ample time for a safe exit."

question: You were parked and have been waiting a long time with your turn signal on to re-enter traffic. However, traffic is heavy. You should:
options: "a: Continue waiting and yielding to traffic in the lane., b: Slowly inch your vehicle into the traffic lane., c: Drive on the shoulder until a gap in traffic appears."
note: "You should 'Continue waiting and yielding to traffic in the lane.'  The DMV handbook states that when entering traffic from a full stop, you must 'leave a large enough space to get up to the speed of traffic.' (Page 23)"

question: If a traffic signal is green, but traffic is blocking the intersection, what should you do?
options: "a: Partially enter the intersection as allowed by traffic., b: Wait and do not enter the intersection until your vehicle can get completely across., c: Drive around the traffic on the shoulder to help ease the congestion."
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway. 'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: You are approaching a green traffic light, but traffic is blocking the intersection. What is the best thing to do?
options: "a: Partially enter the intersection to establish your right-of-way, b: Continue into the intersection and wait for traffic to clear, c: Don't enter the intersection until you can get completely across"
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway. It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red."

question: You should not pass another vehicle
options: "a: On a multi-lane one-way street, b: Where someone is likely to enter or cross the road, c: When a broken yellow line is on the left side of your lane"
note: "You should not pass another vehicle when someone is likely to enter or cross the road. 'Do Not Pass: At crossroads and driveways. - Unless you have enough space to return to your lane.'"

question: If an oncoming vehicle has started to turn left in front of you
options: "a: Maintain your speed and take your right of way, b: Honk your horn to warn the driver and maintain your speed, c: Slow or stop to prevent a collision"
note: "When turning left, do not assume that an oncoming vehicle with its right turn signal on is turning before it reaches you. The driver may have their signal on by mistake or plan to turn just beyond you. Wait for the vehicle to start its turn before beginning the left turn."

question: You are approaching a green traffic light, but traffic is blocking the intersection. What is the best thing to do?
options: "a: Partially enter the intersection to establish your right of way., b: Continue into the intersection and wait for traffic to clear., c: Don't enter the intersection until you can get completely across., d: None of the above"
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway. 'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: You may drive off the paved roadway to pass another vehicle
options: "a: if the shoulder is wide enough to accommodate your vehicle, b: if the vehicle ahead of you is turning left, c: under no circumstances"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Never drive off the paved or main-traveled part of the road to pass.'"

question: You want to pass a vehicle on the road. You should
options: "a: Wait until you can see the entire vehicle in your rearview mirror before merging back into your lane, b: Use your horn to alert the other driver of your intention to pass, c: Pass only if there is enough space in the lane ahead of the vehicle, d: None of the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Unless you have enough space to return to your lane.' This means you should only pass if there is enough space in the lane ahead of the vehicle."

question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
options: "a: After about three seconds., b: When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder., c: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror."
note: "According to page 24 of the DMV handbook, 'Never pass on the left if the driver is signaling a left turn. ... Unless you have enough space to return to your lane.' This indicates that you should only return to your lane when you can safely see the vehicle you have passed in your rearview mirror. Option 'c' is the most accurate description of this situation."

question: As you approach the top of a hill, you should:
options: "a: Speed up slightly., b: Prepare to stop, c: Maintain a steady speed."
note: "You should prepare to stop as you approach the top of a hill because you may not be able to see what is ahead.  The DMV handbook states: 'Do not pass if you are approaching a hill or curve and cannot see if other traffic is approaching. This is very dangerous on one and two lane roads.'"

question: If you are facing a green traffic light but the intersection ahead is blocked by traffic, you should:
options: "a: Turn left and find another route., b: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears., c: Follow the other vehicles and enter the intersection."
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway. It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red."

question: If you plan to pass another vehicle, you should:
options: "a: Not assume the other driver will make space for you to return to your lane., b: Assume the other driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal., c: Assume the other driver will maintain a constant speed."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Before you pass, look ahead for road conditions that may cause other vehicles to move into your lane.'  This means you should 'Not assume the other driver will make space for you to return to your lane.' "

question: It is unlawful to:
options: "a: Pass another vehicle in any marked no passing zone., b: Pass another vehicle over a railroad crossing., c: Both of the above."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 24, 'You must judge whether you have enough space to pass whenever you approach...a railroad crossing.' and, 'Do Not Pass...Within 100 feet of an intersection, bridge, tunnel, railroad crossing, or other hazardous area.' Therefore, the answer is both."

question: To pass on a two-lane road, you should:
options: "a: Sound your horn as you pass., b: Flash your headlights as you pass., c: Judge the distance to any oncoming vehicles."
note: "To safely pass, you must judge whether you have enough space to pass whenever you approach:  - An oncoming vehicle or bicyclist.  - A hill, curve, intersection, or road obstruction.  To safely pass, the hill or curve should be at least one-third of a mile ahead."

question: When passing another vehicle:
options: "a: Pass the vehicle as slowly as possible., b: Drive at the same speed as the vehicle you are passing., c: Pass the vehicle as safely and as quickly as possible."
note: "The DMV handbook states that when passing another vehicle, you should 'speed up to pass the vehicle.' This means that you should pass the vehicle as safely and as quickly as possible."

question: Where is it safe to pass another vehicle?
options: "a: Within an intersection where there are no oncoming vehicles, b: Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing, c: Within a curve where there are no oncoming vehicles"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 24 that, 'You must judge whether you have enough space to pass whenever you approach: An oncoming vehicle or bicyclist., A hill, curve, intersection, or road obstruction.'  The DMV handbook explains on page 24, 'To safely pass, the hill or curve should be at least one-third of a mile ahead.'"

question: You are approaching a green traffic light and traffic is blocking the intersection. What is the best thing to do?
options: "a: Partially enter the intersection to establish your right-of-way., b: Don't enter the intersection until you can get completely across., c: Continue into the intersection and wait for traffic to clear."
note: "Even if you have a green light, do not start across the intersection if there are pedestrians or vehicles blocking your pathway.  It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red."

question: When it is legal to drive off the road to pass another vehicle?
options: "a: If the vehicle ahead is turning left., b: It is not legal under any conditions., c: If there are two or more one-way lanes."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Never drive off the paved or main-traveled part of the road to pass.' (Page 25)"

question: Coasting with the gear shift in neutral is
options: "a: Recommended in the mountains, b: Safe and conserves gas, c: Against the law"
note: "Coasting with the gear shift in neutral is against the law. 'Never drive off the paved or main-traveled part of the road to pass.' This is a dangerous practice."

question: If you are being passed in a no passing zone, you should:
options: "a: Pull off the road., b: Maintain your speed and position., c: Slow down and let the other driver safely return to the drive lane."
note: "If a vehicle is passing you or signals that they plan on passing, allow the vehicle to pass. Maintain your lane position and your speed."

question: When passing on the left of a vehicle, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
options: "a: After about three seconds., b: When you can no longer see the vehicle over your right shoulder., c: When you can see the front of the vehicle in your rearview mirror."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you should return to your original lane when you can see the front of the vehicle in your rearview mirror.  This indicates you have safely passed the vehicle and can return to your lane."

question: When passing, you should move back into the right lane when:
options: "a: You are one vehicle length ahead of the passed vehicle., b: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror., c: You are 50 feet ahead of the passed vehicle."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, you should move back into the right lane when you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. 'Signal and return to your original lane.'"

question: Which of the following is the proper procedure for parallel parking?
options: "a: Drive forward into the space without stopping., b: Stop next to the vehicle behind the open space and then drive forward into the space., c: Stop next to the vehicle in front of the open space and then back into the space."
note: "The DMV handbook describes the steps for parallel parking on page 26. The correct answer is option c, 'Stop next to the vehicle in front of the open space and then back into the space.'"

question: In addition to setting your parking brake, what should you do when parking on a hill?
options: "a: Make sure the front vehicle wheels are parallel to the road., b: Make sure your vehicle is left in the 'neutral' position., c: Make sure your vehicle is in the 'park' position or in gear."
note: "When you park on a hill, your vehicle could roll due to equipment failure.  Remember to set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park, or in gear for manual transmission."

question: When parking your vehicle on any hill
options: "a: Your front wheels should be parallel to the road if there is no curb, b: Use your parking brake and leave the vehicle in gear or 'park', c: One of your rear wheels should touch the curb"
note: "To prevent your vehicle from rolling, you must 'set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park, or in gear for manual transmission.'"

question: To safely back their vehicle, drivers should NOT
options: "a: Tap their horn before backing up, b: Check in front and behind their vehicle before they get in, c: Look over their right shoulder as they back up"
note: "Before backing up, it is important to check for hazards in front and behind the vehicle. 'Observe traffic and check appropriate blind spots.' (Page 26)"

question: Parallel parking is when the
options: "a: front wheels are turned toward the street, b: vehicle is in line with other parked vehicles, c: rear wheels are touching the curb"
note: "Parallel parking is defined as parking 'in line with the road and other parked vehicles'.  The DMV handbook states that on page 26: 'Parallel parking is when you park in line with the road and other parked vehicles.'"

question: When you park on a hill, your vehicle could roll due to an equipment failure. Remember
options: "a: leave the vehicle in neutral, b: set the parking brake, c: set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park"
note: "The DMV Handbook states: 'Remember to set the parking brake and leave the vehicle in park, or in gear for manual transmission.'"

question: Backing your vehicle is:
options: "a: Always dangerous to do., b: Dangerous if you have a helper., c: Only dangerous in large vehicles."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Stay aware of what is behind you when backing up.' This implies backing up is always dangerous.  'To back up in a straight line: 1. Traffic check. Observe traffic and check appropriate blind spots.'"

question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
options: "a: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road., b: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road., c: Keep your wheels straight."
note: "To park on a hill headed downhill, turn your front wheels into the curb or right toward the side of the road."

question: When backing up:
options: "a: Look through the rear window., b: Press hard on the gas pedal., c: Rely only on your rearview mirror."
note: "When backing up, 'To back up in a straight line: 1. **Traffic check.** Observe traffic and check appropriate blind spots., 2. **Signal.** Activate the turn signal before pulling up to the curb. Cancel the turn signal once completed., 3. **Check your blind spots.** Look in your rearview mirror and over your shoulder for approaching vehicles and pedestrians., 4. **Begin backing up.** Back in a straight line for three vehicle lengths while remaining within three feet of the curb. Stay aware of what is behind you when backing up., 5. **Control.** To maintain control of the vehicle, back at a smooth, safe speed and adjust the steering wheel when needed. Practice until you can keep the vehicle straight. Repeat steps 1 and 2 to pull away from the curb.'"

question: When parking your vehicle parallel to the curb on a level street:
options: "a: Your front wheels must be turned toward the street., b: Your wheels must be within 18 inches of the curb., c: One of your rear wheels must touch the curb."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, when parallel parking your vehicle, 'Your vehicle should now be parallel and within 18 inches of the curb.'"

question: Left sign or the lane and sign should be used to warn of the reduction in the number of traffic lanes in the direction of travel on a multi lane highway. When parking uphill on a 2 way street with no curb, your front wheels should be
options: "a: Turn to the left toward the street, b: Turn to the right away from the street, c: Parallel with the pavement, d: Turn the wheels toward the curb"
note: "To prevent rolling downhill when parked on a hill with no curb, turn your front wheels to the right away from the street. 'Headed uphill: Turn your front wheels away from the curb (left - towards the center of the road) and let your vehicle roll back a few inches. The wheel should gently touch the curb. '"

question: When parking on a hill on a two-way street with no curb, you should:
options: "a: Turn your front wheels to the left away from the side of the road., b: Park at a slight angle with rear wheels closer to the road's edge., c: Turn your front wheels to the right toward the side of the road."
note: "To prevent your vehicle from rolling into traffic if the brakes fail, you should turn your front wheels to the right, toward the side of the road.  'Turn the wheels so the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail. Downhill: turn the wheels toward the curb.' "

question: If you park facing uphill on a street with a curb, set the parking brake and:
options: "a: Turn the front wheels toward the curb., b: Turn the front wheels away from the curb., c: Leave the front wheels straight."
note: "To prevent your vehicle from rolling backwards, turn the front wheels away from the curb (left towards the center of the road) and let your vehicle roll back a few inches. The wheel should gently touch the curb."

question: If you park facing uphill where there is no curb, set the parking brake and:
options: "a: Turn your wheels toward the edge of the road., b: Turn your wheels away from the edge of the road., c: Keep your wheels facing straight."
note: "When parking on a hill without a curb, you should turn your wheels toward the edge of the road to prevent your vehicle from rolling down the hill if the brakes fail.  As quoted in the DMV handbook: 'Headed either uphill or downhill when there is no curb: Turn the wheels so the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail. Downhill: turn the wheels toward the curb.'"

question: In which of the following scenarios should your wheels not be pointed straight ahead?
options: "a: When waiting to make a left turn at a traffic light., b: When parked on a hill or sloping driveway., c: When parked on the side of a level roadway where there is no curb."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 27 that when parked on a hill or sloping driveway, your wheels should be turned so the vehicle will not roll into the street. This is to prevent the vehicle from rolling if the brakes fail."

question: Which way do you turn your front wheels to park downhill next to a curb?
options: "a: Into the curb, b: Away from the curb, c: Parallel to the curb"
note: "To park downhill next to a curb, turn your front wheels into the curb. This will prevent your car from rolling into the street if your brakes fail. 'Headed downhill: Turn your front wheels into the curb or right toward the side of the road.'"

question: You want to park downhill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which way do you turn your front wheels?
options: "a: Straight ahead, b: Right, c: Left"
note: "When parking downhill on a two-way road with no curb, turn your front wheels to the right (toward the shoulder of the road). This will prevent your vehicle from rolling into oncoming traffic if the brakes fail.  'Turn the wheels so the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail. Downhill: turn the wheels toward the curb.'"

question: Who can legally park next to curb painted blue?
options: "a: Someone who is either picking up or dropping off passengers at this location., b: A person who is disabled and has a special placard or vehicle license plate for disabled persons., c: A person who will only be parked at the curb for less than 15 minutes."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Blue: Parking for a disabled person or someone driving a disabled person with a special placard or special license plate.'"

question: What color curb does not allow vehicles to stop or park?
options: "a: Yellow., b: Red., c: White."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Red: No stopping, standing, or parking.'"

question: You may not 'double park'
options: "a: At any time, b: Except when making a delivery, c: Except while waiting in the vehicle"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 28 that 'Never park or leave your vehicle... Double parked.'"

question: Parking is not allowed
options: "a: In a tunnel, b: On the road side of a parked vehicle, c: All of the above"
note: "The DMV handbook lists various parking restrictions. 'Never park or leave your vehicle: In a tunnel...'  '...On a sidewalk, partially blocking a sidewalk, or in front of a driveway.' '...Double parked.' "

question: Parking is never permitted
options: "a: In a crosshatched (diagonal) pattern space, b: In a bicycle lane unless otherwise posted, c: Twenty feet from a railroad track"
note: "According to page 28, 'Never park or leave your vehicle... In the crosshatched (diagonal lines) area next to a designated disabled parking space.'"

question: A curb painted blue means parking is:
options: "a: Allowed for no longer than 15 minutes., b: Only allowed when picking up or dropping off passengers., c: For disabled persons with a special placard or plate."
note: "According to page 28, 'Blue: Parking for a disabled person or someone driving a disabled person with a special placard or special license plate.'"

question: A curb painted red means:
options: "a: Loading zone., b: The area is reserved for picking up or dropping off passengers., c: No parking"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Red: No stopping, standing, or parking.'"

question: A white painted curb indicates a:
options: "a: Loading zone for freight or passengers., b: Loading zone for passengers or mail only., c: Loading zone for freight only."
note: "According to page 28 of the DMV handbook, 'White: Stop only long enough to pick up or drop off passengers.'"

question: If it is necessary to make an emergency stop while driving on an interstate, you should:
options: "a: Sound your horn at passing cars to get their attention., b: Get out of your vehicle and flag down the first vehicle that passes., c: Pull off the road"
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 28, 'If you must stop on a freeway, park completely off the pavement and stay in your vehicle with the doors locked until help arrives.'"

question: It is illegal to park your vehicle:
options: "a: In an unmarked crosswalk., b: Within three feet of a private driveway., c: In a bicycle lane."
note: "According to page 28, 'Never park or leave your vehicle... On a marked or unmarked crosswalk.'"

question: Placard abuse will result in:
options: "a: Placard revocation only., b: Only a fine., c: Placard revocation"
note: "Placard abuse will result in Placard revocation. This information can be found on Page 28, 'Illegal Parking', under the 'Blue' colored curb description."

question: You may not park your vehicle:
options: "a: On the side of the freeway in an emergency., b: Next to a red painted curb., c: Within 100 feet of an elementary school."
note: "According to page 28, 'Never park or leave your vehicle... - Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant or fire station driveway. - Within 20 feet of an unmarked or marked crosswalk, or within 15 feet of a crosswalk where a curb extension is present. - Between a safety zone and curb. - Double parked. - On the wrong side of the street or on a freeway, except: - In an emergency. - When a law enforcement officer requires a stop. - Where a stop is specifically permitted. - Where a No Parking sign is posted. - On a marked or unmarked crosswalk. - On a sidewalk, partially blocking a sidewalk, or in front of a driveway. - Within three feet of a sidewalk ramp for disabled persons. - In front of or on a curb that provides wheelchair access to a sidewalk. - In the crosshatched (diagonal lines) area next to a designated disabled parking space. - In a space designated for parking or fueling zero-emission vehicles, unless you are driving a zero-emission vehicle. - In a tunnel or on a bridge, unless permitted by signs.  -  Red: No stopping, standing, or parking.'"

question: You must show proof of insurance to law enforcement:
options: "a: Only if you are involved in a collision., b: If you are involved in a collision or stopped for a citation., c: Only if you are stopped and cited."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 29, 'The driver of a stopped vehicle must produce a driver's license, proof of insurance, and vehicle registration when stopped by law enforcement.' This implies that proof of insurance is required during a traffic stop, not just when involved in a collision."

question: A solid yellow arrow on a traffic signal means:
options: "a: You should speed up so you can make the turn before the light changes., b: You do not need to signal to turn from the indicated lane., c: You should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic."
note: "A yellow arrow means the protected turning time is ending. The signal will change soon. If you cannot stop safely or you are already in the intersection, cautiously complete your turn. Pay attention to the next signal. It could be a: - Green or red traffic signal light. - Red arrow."

question: A steady red arrow displayed on a traffic light means:
options: "a: Drivers cannot turn in the indicated direction., b: Drivers may turn in the indicated direction after coming to a complete stop., c: Drivers may turn in the indicated direction."
note: "A red arrow means STOP. Do not turn at a red arrow. Remain stopped until a green traffic signal light or green arrow appears."

question: A steady yellow traffic signal light is a warning that the light is about to change to red. If you are already within the intersection when a green light changes to yellow, you should:
options: "a: Stop., b: Continue moving and clear the intersection safely., c: Increase your speed so as not to cause an accident."
note: "A yellow traffic signal light means CAUTION. The light is about to turn red. When you see a yellow traffic signal light, stop, if you can do so safely. If you cannot stop safely, cautiously cross the intersection."

question: Before stopping your vehicle at a traffic signal or sign, you should:
options: "a: Press down hard on the accelerator., b: Check your mirrors for surrounding traffic., c: Set the parking brake."
note: "Before stopping at a traffic signal or sign, it is crucial to be aware of your surroundings to make safe driving decisions. The DMV handbook states that you should check your mirrors for surrounding traffic before entering an intersection. This ensures that you are aware of other vehicles that may also be approaching the intersection and helps prevent collisions."

question: It is legal to make a left turn at a red traffic light after stopping only if:
options: "a: You are traveling on a two-way street and turning onto a two-way street., b: You are traveling on a one-way street and turning onto another one-way street., c: You yield to all other traffic at the intersection."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 33, 'You may turn left against a red light when you are turning from a one-way street onto a one-way street.'"

question: What does a traffic signal with a yellow left arrow indicate?
options: "a: Drivers should prepare to yield to oncoming traffic., b: The protected left turn is about to end., c: Both of the above."
note: "A yellow arrow means the protected turning time is ending. The signal will change soon. If you cannot stop safely or you are already in the intersection, cautiously complete your turn. Pay attention to the next signal. It could be a: - Green or red traffic signal light. - Red arrow."

question: What is the difference between traffic lights with red arrows and those with solid red lights?
options: "a: Red arrows are only used to stop traffic which is turning., b: Red arrows are only used for protected turn lanes., c: You cannot turn on a red arrow"
note: "A red arrow means STOP. Do not turn at a red arrow. Remain stopped until a green traffic signal light or green arrow appears."

question: When approaching an intersection that is controlled by a flashing red traffic signal, you must:
options: "a: Come to a complete stop, b: Reduce your speed and proceed with caution., c: Come to a complete stop and remain stopped as long as the light is red."
note: "A flashing red traffic signal light means STOP. After stopping, you may go when it is safe."

question: You are approaching an intersection at the posted speed limit when the signal turns yellow. You should:
options: "a: Slow down and proceed through the intersection without caution., b: Speed up to cross the intersection before the light turns red., c: Stop before entering the intersection"
note: "A yellow traffic signal light means CAUTION. The light is about to turn red. When you see a yellow traffic signal light, stop, if you can do so safely. If you cannot stop safely, cautiously cross the intersection."

question: You are approaching an intersection where a traffic signal is displaying a steady yellow light. If you have not already entered the intersection, you should:
options: "a: Speed up to beat the red light., b: Reduce you speed and proceed carefully through the intersection., c: Come to a safe stop."
note: "A yellow traffic signal light means CAUTION. The light is about to turn red. When you see a yellow traffic signal light, stop, if you can do so safely. If you cannot stop safely, cautiously cross the intersection."

question: You are required to stop your vehicle:
options: "a: At any intersection where a police officer orders you to stop., b: Where there is a red traffic light., c: Both of the above."
note: "Both options are correct.  A red light means stop, and a police officer has authority to order a vehicle to stop.  'A red traffic signal light means STOP.' 'Obey any direction, order, or signal given by a law enforcement officer'"

question: The traffic light is green and you want to drive straight through an intersection. If a car is already in the intersection and is making a turn, you must
options: "a: Enter the intersection and then stop, b: Drive through the intersection. You have the right-of-way, c: Let that car complete its turn before you enter the intersection"
note: "Even if you have a green light, you must still yield to vehicles, bicyclists, or pedestrians already in the intersection. 'You should still stop for any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian in the intersection. Only proceed if you have enough space without creating a danger to any oncoming vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian.' "

question: When is it safe to enter an intersection on a solid green light?
options: "a: when you can go around the traffic already in the intersection, b: when you have enough space to cross the intersection before the light turns red, c: when you cannot completely cross the intersection"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Only proceed if you have enough space without creating a danger to any oncoming vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian. Do not enter the intersection if you cannot get completely across before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: A flashing yellow traffic signal at an intersection means:
options: "a: You should treat the signal like a stop sign., b: Stop. Yield to all cross traffic before crossing in the intersection., c: Slow down and be alert at the upcoming intersection."
note: "A flashing yellow traffic signal means CAUTION. 'A flashing yellow traffic signal light is a warning to PROCEED WITH CAUTION. Slow down and be alert. You do not need to stop.'"

question: A steady green traffic light at an intersection means:
options: "a: Increase your speed., b: Adjust your mirrors., c: You may continue through the intersection at a safe and reasonable speed"
note: "A solid green traffic signal light means GO. You should still stop for any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian in the intersection. Only proceed if you have enough space without creating a danger to any oncoming vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian."

question: At a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if:
options: "a: You first come to a complete stop., b: You wait until the light changes., c: You are in the proper lane and the roadway is clear."
note: "A green arrow means GO in the direction the arrow is pointing. The green arrow allows you to make a protected turn. Oncoming vehicles are stopped by a red traffic signal light. "

question: It is against the law to enter an intersection when:
options: "a: You can't get all the way across before the light turns red., b: The light is flashing yellow and you didn't stop first., c: The light is yellow and you cannot stop safely."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 34, 'Do not enter the intersection if you cannot get completely across before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: On a green arrow, you must:
options: "a: Yield to any vehicle, b: Yield to pedestrians only in the intersection., c: Wait four seconds before proceeding."
note: "A green arrow means GO in the direction the arrow is pointing. The green arrow allows you to make a protected turn. Oncoming vehicles are stopped by a red traffic signal light. "

question: What should a driver do when approaching a traffic control signal that is not in operation?
options: "a: Come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way before entering the intersection., b: If the intersection is clear, c: Drive quickly through the intersection to get out of the way of other vehicles."
note: "When a traffic light is not working, stop as if the intersection is controlled by STOP signs in all directions. Then proceed cautiously when it is safe to do so."

question: What should you do if a pedestrian is still in the crosswalk after the 'DON'T WALK' sign begins to flash and your light has turned green?
options: "a: Wait until the pedestrian is out of your path before proceeding., b: Wait until the pedestrian signals that it is okay for you to proceed., c: Wait until the pedestrian has crossed the street completely before proceeding."
note: "Even if the 'DON'T WALK' sign is flashing and your light has turned green, you must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk. The DMV handbook states, 'Drivers must yield to pedestrians, even if the DON'T WALK light is flashing.'"

question: When coming to a corner where there is a stop sign, you must first stop
options: "a: After crossing the crosswalk, b: Out far enough to see cross traffic, c: In back of the crosswalk"
note: "According to page 35, 'Make a full stop before entering the crosswalk or at the limit line. If there is no limit line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection.'"

question: At a stop sign there is no stop line or crosswalk. You must stop
options: "a: Before you enter the intersection, b: After you enter the intersection if you have a clear view of traffic on the intersecting roadway, c: At the next crosswalk"
note: "According to page 35 of the DMV handbook, 'Make a full stop before entering the crosswalk or at the limit line. If there is no limit line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection. Check traffic in all directions before proceeding.'"

question: At an intersection with a stop sign, you must:
options: "a: Stop and check for traffic before proceeding, b: Slow down and yield to cross traffic, c: Proceed with caution without stopping, d: None of the above"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Make a full stop before entering the crosswalk or at the limit line. If there is no limit line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection. Check traffic in all directions before proceeding.'"

question: When you approach an octagonal sign, you must:
options: "a: Slow., b: Stop., c: Turn."
note: "An octagonal sign is a stop sign. 'Make a full stop before entering the crosswalk or at the limit line. If there is no limit line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection. Check traffic in all directions before proceeding.'"

question: Blue traffic signs offer information on:
options: "a: Motorist services., b: Construction and maintenance., c: Mileage information"
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 36, 'White Rectangular Sign' communicates many important rules you must obey."

question: Signs with orange backgrounds are:
options: "a: General warning signs., b: Construction and maintenance warning signs., c: Regulatory signs."
note: "According to page 36, 'Highway Construction and Maintenance Signs' are the ones with orange backgrounds."

question: Temporary signs used in construction and maintenance work areas:
options: "a: Have a red background with green writing., b: Have an orange background with black writing., c: Have a yellow background with blue writing."
note: "The DMV handbook states on Page 36 that 'Diamond-Shaped Sign Warns you of specific road conditions and dangers ahead.'"

question: Various traffic control devices in construction and maintenance work areas are the color:
options: "a: Red., b: Orange., c: Yellow."
note: "Traffic control devices in construction and maintenance work areas are typically orange. This can be found on page 36, where the DMV Handbook states:'Highway Construction and Maintenance Signs'. The signs shown in the image have black lettering and symbols on an orange background."

question: What do pennant-shaped signs indicate?
options: "a: A school crossing, b: A No Passing Zone, c: Yield"
note: "Pennant-shaped signs are no-passing zone signs. They are yellow with black lettering and are placed on the left side of two-way roads to warn drivers that passing is not safe in that area."

question: What shape is a railroad advance warning sign?
options: "a: Pentagon, b: Round, c: Crossbuck"
note: "The DMV handbook states that a Yellow and Black Circular Sign or X-shaped Sign  is a railroad crossing sign. 'R R You are approaching a railroad crossing. Look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop.'  A crossbuck is an X-shaped sign."

question: Regulatory signs are
options: "a: Suggestions, b: Law, c: Warnings"
note: "On page 37, the DMV handbook states that 'Red and White Regulatory Sign Follow the sign's instruction.'"

question: A traffic sign with a red circle around and a slash over a symbol means
options: "a: The maneuver shown by the symbol is not allowed, b: The maneuver shown on the sign should be executed with extreme caution, c: Do not drive faster than the posted speed limit"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'The picture inside the circle shows what you cannot do and may be shown with words.'"

question: The first sign drivers see when approaching a highway-rail intersection is usually
options: "a: A crossbuck sign, b: A speed limit sign, c: An advance warning sign"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Yellow and Black Circular Sign or X-shaped Sign You are approaching a railroad crossing. Look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Let any trains pass before you proceed.'"

question: "No passing zone" signs tell drivers:
options: "a: To speed up slightly., b: That it is not safe to pass., c: To maintain a steady speed."
note: "The DMV handbook explains on page 37 that 'No Passing' signs indicate 'that it is not safe to pass'."

question: A diamond-shaped sign means:
options: "a: Yield., b: Stop., c: Warning."
note: "A diamond-shaped sign warns you of specific road conditions and dangers ahead."

question: A pentagon-shaped sign is a:
options: "a: Stop sign., b: Regulatory sign., c: School zone or school crossing sign."
note: "The DMV handbook states that a 5-sided sign indicates a school zone or school crossing."

question: Construction zone signs are generally:
options: "a: Square or rectangular with white and red coloring., b: Round or octagonal with black and yellow coloring., c: Diamond-shaped or rectangular with orange and black coloring."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 37, 'Diamond-Shaped Sign' Warns you of specific road conditions and dangers ahead."

question: Regulatory signs are:
options: "a: Green., b: Yellow., c: White."
note: "The answer is 'c' White.  This is stated on page 37 of the DMV handbook.  'Red And White Regulatory Sign, Follow the sign's instruction.'"

question: What should you do when reaching an intersection where a person operating a motorized wheelchair has entered the crosswalk?
options: "a: Remain stopped behind the crosswalk line until the motorized wheelchair has safely finished crossing., b: Remain stopped behind the nearest crosswalk line until the motorized wheelchair is beyond the range of your vehicle., c: Assume right-of-way if the motorized wheelchair stops in the crosswalk."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Pedestrians always have the right-of-way.' This includes people with disabilities using a wheelchair. Therefore, you should remain stopped until the motorized wheelchair has safely finished crossing."

question: At intersections without Stop or Yield signs, you must
options: "a: Yield to traffic and pedestrians already in the intersection, b: Yield to the vehicle on your right if it reaches the intersection at the same time as you, c: All of the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'The vehicle that arrives to the intersection first has the right-of-way. However, if a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.'"

question: What happens if two vehicles reach at the same time an intersection with four-way stop signs?
options: "a: The driver on the right yields to the driver on the left, b: The driver on the left yields to the driver on the right, c: The first vehicle to reach the intersection must yield"
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'If a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.'"

question: At a T-intersection with no signs or signals, you must yield to
options: "a: Traffic on the road you are entering, b: Traffic on the road you are leaving, c: Pedestrians in the crosswalk, d: None of the above"
note: "According to page 38, 'Vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians on the through road (continuing to go straight) have the right-of-way.' This means that the vehicle entering the T-intersection must yield to traffic on the road it is leaving."

question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you:
options: "a: Must yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict., b: Must yield to vehicles only on your right., c: Should slow down but never stop."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 38, 'Slow down and be ready to stop to let any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian pass before you proceed.'"

question: At intersections, crosswalks, and railroad crossings, you should always:
options: "a: Stop, b: Look to the sides of your vehicle to see what is coming., c: Slowly pass vehicles that seem to be stopped for no reason."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Before entering an intersection, look left, right, and ahead to check for vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians. Be prepared to slow down and stop if necessary.'"

question: If there is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane, you should:
options: "a: Make sure the pedestrian can see you before proceeding., b: Cautiously drive around the pedestrian., c: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing."
note: "Pedestrians always have the right-of-way, even in unmarked crosswalks. 'Before entering an intersection, look left, right, and ahead to check for vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians. Be prepared to slow down and stop if necessary. Pedestrians always have the right-of-way.'"

question: What is an important step in turning?
options: "a: Check traffic in all directions., b: Increase your speed., c: Always move to the left lane."
note: "The DMV handbook states that before entering an intersection, 'look left, right, and ahead to check for vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians. Be prepared to slow down and stop if necessary.'"

question: You should yield to a pedestrian:
options: "a: Only if they are in a crosswalk., b: At all times, c: Only if the traffic lights are in the pedestrian's favor."
note: "Pedestrians always have the right-of-way. 'Pedestrians always have the right-of-way.'"

question: You want to make a right turn at the corner. A pedestrian with a guide dog is at the corner ready to cross the street in front of you. Before making your right turn, you should:
options: "a: Turn off your engine until the person crosses the street., b: Tell the pedestrian when to cross the street., c: Wait until the person crosses the street."
note: "Pedestrians always have the right-of-way. 'Before entering an intersection, look left, right, and ahead to check for vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians. Be prepared to slow down and stop if necessary. Pedestrians always have the right-of-way.'"

question: What should a driver do who is stopped at an intersection and wants to make a left turn?
options: "a: Turn immediately if there are no pedestrians., b: Take the right-of-way turn before oncoming traffic., c: Give the right-of-way to any approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous."
note: "When turning left, you must check for pedestrians. 'Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous.'"

question: It is against the law to enter an intersection or crosswalk when
options: "a: The light is yellow, b: The light is flashing red, c: You cannot cross without obstructing traffic from either side."
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 39 that it is against the law to block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red."

question: At an intersection with stop signs at all four (or more) corners, when two cars arrive at the same time you must yield the right-of-way to the driver
options: "a: On your right, b: On your left, c: Signaling a turn"
note: "The DMV handbook states: 'If a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.'"

question: When you reach a corner without a traffic light or sign at the same time as vehicles on the cross street, you must yield the right-of-way to
options: "a: The driver on your right, b: The driver on your left, c: Neither driver"
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 39, 'If a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.'"

question: If a driver ahead of you has stopped at a crosswalk, you should
options: "a: Change lanes look carefully and pass, b: Tap your horn to let the driver know you are waiting, c: Stop then proceed when safe"
note: "You must stop for pedestrians at a crosswalk. 'Pedestrians always have the right-of-way. Here are some right-of-way rules at intersections:  - Green traffic signal light: Proceed with caution. Pedestrians have the right-of-way.'"

question: You face a green light, but traffic on the other side of the intersection does not allow you to travel all the way through the intersection. What must you do?
options: "a: Wait for the next green light, b: Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection, c: Enter the intersection and wait until traffic ahead clears"
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.
