question: You want to turn left at an intersection ahead. A car reaches the intersection from the opposite direction and moves straight ahead. You
options: "a: Must wait for the car to go through before you turn, b: May not enter the intersection to prepare for your left turn if the light is green, c: Can turn left. You have the right of way"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'When entering traffic, you must proceed with caution and yield to the traffic already occupying the lanes.' Therefore, you must wait for the car to go through before you turn."

question: A driver who approaches an intersection
options: "a: Must yield the right-of-way to traffic already in the intersection, b: Has the right-of-way over traffic already in the intersection, c: Must drive straight through the intersection even if another vehicle is already in the intersection"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'When entering traffic, you must proceed with caution and yield to the traffic already occupying the lanes.' This statement clearly indicates that a driver approaching an intersection must yield to traffic already in the intersection."

question: You should not start across an intersection if you know you will...
options: "a: Block the intersection when the light turns red., b: Unless you enter the intersection on a yellow light., c: Unless you enter the intersection on a green light., d: None of the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 39: 'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: If you have a green light but traffic is blocking the intersection, you should
options: "a: Enter the intersection and wait until traffic clears, b: Merge into another lane and try to go around the traffic, c: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears, d: None of the above"
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.  'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: You are approaching an intersection with a green light. If the intersection is blocked by other vehicles, you should:
options: "a: Enter the intersection and wait until it clears, b: Merge into another lane and try to go around the traffic, c: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears, d: None of the above"
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.  'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'"

question: A driver should:
options: "a: Assume all drivers automatically obey the right-of-way rules., b: Assume most drivers obey the right-of-way rules., c: Always be prepared to yield the right-of-way."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Never assume that other drivers will give you the right-of-way. Give up your right-of-way when it will help prevent collisions.'"

question: At an intersection with stop signs on all corners, yield the right-of-way to any driver:
options: "a: On your left., b: Who arrived before you., c: Across from your vehicle."
note: "The DMV handbook states: 'The vehicle that arrives to the intersection first has the right-of-way.'"

question: Blocking an intersection during "rush hour" traffic is not permitted:
options: "a: Unless you entered the intersection on a green light., b: Under any circumstances, c: Unless you have the right-of-way or a green light."
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.  This is found on page 39."

question: Drivers turning left must yield to:
options: "a: Oncoming vehicles traveling straight or turning right., b: Passing cars., c: No one in particular."
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 39, 'Turning left: Check for pedestrians. Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous.'  The right-of-way is for the vehicles coming straight or turning right."

question: If you have a green light but traffic is blocking the intersection, you should:
options: "a: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears., b: Enter the intersection and wait until traffic clears., c: Merge into another lane and try to go around the traffic."
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 39, 'It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red.'  Therefore, you should not enter the intersection if you cannot get completely across before the light turns red."

question: The driver ahead of you stops at a crosswalk. What should you do?
options: "a: Cautiously pass the vehicle at 10 mph or slower., b: Stop, c: Change lanes"
note: "You should always stop for pedestrians in a crosswalk. 'Pedestrians always have the right-of-way.'"

question: When arriving to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as vehicles to your right and left, you should:
options: "a: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your left., b: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your right., c: Wait until there are no vehicles at the intersection before proceeding."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 39:'If a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right.'"

question: When planning to pass another vehicle, you should:
options: "a: Not count on other drivers to make room for you., b: Assume the driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal., c: Assume the driver will maintain a constant speed."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Never assume that other drivers will give you the right-of-way.'"

question: When should you yield your legal right-of-way?
options: "a: Often, b: Whenever it helps prevent collisions., c: Never. It confuses other drivers."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Give up your right-of-way when it will help prevent collisions.'"

question: When turning left at an intersection:
options: "a: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians., b: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you., c: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'Turning left: Check for pedestrians. Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous.'"

question: You may legally block an intersection:
options: "a: If you entered the intersection on the green light., b: During rush hour traffic., c: Under no circumstances."
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red."

question: You reach an intersection with stop signs on all four corners at the same time as the driver on your left. Who has the right-of-way?
options: "a: The driver on your left has the right-of-way., b: You have the right-of-way., c: Whoever is signaling to make a turn has the right-of-way."
note: "If you approach a stop sign and there is a stop sign on all four corners, stop first and proceed as above. However, if a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist gets to the intersection at the same time as you, give the right-of-way to the vehicle, pedestrian, or bicyclist on your right."

question: You should not start across an intersection if you know you will block the intersection when the light turns red:
options: "a: Under any circumstances., b: Unless you entered the intersection on a yellow light., c: Unless you entered the intersection on a green light."
note: "It is against the law to stop or block an intersection where there is not enough space to completely cross before the traffic signal light turns red."

question: You want to turn left at an upcoming corner. Yield the right-of-way to:
options: "a: Oncoming vehicles also turning left., b: All approaching vehicles., c: Pedestrians on the sidewalk waiting for a \"Walk\" signal."
note: "When turning left, check for pedestrians. Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian or approaching vehicle that is close enough to be dangerous."

question: You are entering a roundabout with multiple lanes, and you need to turn right at the intersection. You must
options: "a: Choose either lane and exit in the lane you entered, b: Choose the right-hand lane and exit in the right-hand lane, c: Choose the left-hand lane and exit"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, when entering a roundabout with multiple lanes to make a right turn, you should 'Choose the right lane and exit in the right lane.' This is described on Page 40 in the section titled 'Roundabouts.'"

question: You are entering a roundabout with multiple lanes, and you need to go straight through the intersection. You must
options: "a: Choose either lane and exit in the lane you entered, b: Choose the right-hand lane and exit in the right-hand lane, c: Choose the left-hand lane and exit"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'If the roundabout has multiple lanes, choose your entry or exit lane based on your destination.'  To go straight, you can enter either lane and exit in the same lane. This is confirmed by the example provided, 'Go straight (red car): Choose either lane. Exit in the lane you entered.'"

question: Once in the roundabout, drivers travel
options: "a: In a counter-clockwise direction, b: In a clockwise direction, c: In both directions"
note: "In a roundabout, traffic travels in one direction around a central island.  'Travel in a counter-clockwise direction. Do not stop or pass.'"

question: As you enter into a roundabout, you should slow down and:
options: "a: Yield to any crossing pedestrians and bicyclists., b: Yield to any car already within the roundabout., c: Both of the above."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'In a roundabout, traffic travels in one direction around a central island.'  'How to use a roundabout: 1. Slow down as you approach. 2. Yield to all traffic already in the roundabout. 3. Enter heading to the right when there is a big enough gap in traffic to merge safely.'"

question: If a child is about to run into the street, you should:
options: "a: Start to prepare to slow down., b: Flash your headlights., c: Sound a sharp blast of your horn."
note: "The DMV handbook states that when you see a pedestrian crossing a roadway with or without a crosswalk, you 'must' use caution, reduce your speed, or stop to allow the pedestrian to safely finish crossing."

question: When approaching a roundabout, you should always:
options: "a: Increase your speed., b: Decrease your speed., c: Maintain your speed."
note: "When approaching a roundabout, you should always slow down to yield to traffic already in the roundabout. 'Slow down as you approach.'  This is found on page 40 of the DMV handbook."

question: When using a roundabout, drivers should:
options: "a: Stop in the middle of the roundabout., b: Yield to traffic already in the roundabout., c: Yield to entering traffic."
note: "According to page 40, 'In a roundabout, traffic travels in one direction around a central island.' 'How to use a roundabout:'  'Yield to all traffic already in the roundabout.'"

question: Pedestrians crossing at corners have the right-of-way
options: "a: Only when a crosswalk is painted on the street, b: Whether or not a crosswalk is marked, c: Only at open intersections"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks.'"

question: Which of the following should NOT be done when driving near pedestrians
options: "a: Drive on a sidewalk, b: Pass a vehicle that has stopped at a crosswalk, c: All of the above"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, all of the listed options are incorrect driving behaviors near pedestrians. Option a states that it is illegal to drive on a sidewalk, option b states that drivers should not pass a vehicle that has stopped at a crosswalk. The DMV handbook states, 'Do not pass a vehicle stopped at a crosswalk. You may not be able to see a pedestrian crossing the street.' The DMV handbook also states, 'You may drive on or cross a sidewalk to enter or exit a driveway or alley.'"

question: There is no crosswalk and you are a pedestrian crossing your lane ahead. You should
options: "a: make eye contact with and then pass the pedestrian, b: slow down as you pass the pedestrian, c: stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing the street"
note: "Pedestrians always have the right-of-way. 'When there is a pedestrian crossing a roadway with or without a crosswalk, you **must** use caution, reduce your speed, or stop to allow the pedestrian to safely finish crossing.'"

question: At a crosswalk:
options: "a: You must yield to pedestrians., b: Pedestrians must yield to you., c: Construction workers must yield to you."
note: "Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks."

question: Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian who is:
options: "a: In a marked crosswalk., b: In any crosswalk or intersection., c: Crossing any street."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, on page 41, 'Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks.' The DMV handbook also states that drivers must 'use caution, reduce your speed, or stop to allow the pedestrian to safely finish crossing.' Therefore, you must give the right-of-way to any pedestrian who is crossing any street."

question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, what should the motorist do?
options: "a: Continue ahead. The motorist has the right-of-way., b: Wait for the pedestrians to cross the street., c: Pull to the right and go around the pedestrians."
note: "Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks. 'If there is a limit line before the crosswalk, stop at the limit line and allow pedestrians to cross the street.'"

question: If pedestrians are illegally crossing in the middle of the street instead of in a crosswalk, you:
options: "a: Must stop for them., b: Do not have to stop for them., c: Should honk your horn at them."
note: "Even though they are crossing illegally, you must still stop for them.  'When there is a pedestrian crossing a roadway with or without a crosswalk, you **must** use caution, reduce your speed, or stop to allow the pedestrian to safely finish crossing.'"

question: If you see a pedestrian using a guide dog or carrying a white cane:
options: "a: The pedestrian must yield the right-of-way., b: You must yield the right-of-way., c: Honk your horn to let them know you are there."
note: "Pedestrians using guide dogs or white canes have the right-of-way at all times.  'Be careful when you are turning or backing up. This is particularly important if you are driving a hybrid or electric vehicle because blind pedestrians rely on sound to know there is a vehicle nearby.'"

question: Pedestrians crossing at corners have the right-of-way:
options: "a: Only at controlled intersections., b: Only when a crosswalk is painted on the street., c: Whether or not a crosswalk is marked."
note: "Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks. 'Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks.'"

question: There is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane ahead. You should:
options: "a: Make eye contact with and then pass the pedestrian., b: Slow down as you pass the pedestrian., c: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing the street."
note: "Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks. If there is a limit line before the crosswalk, stop at the limit line and allow pedestrians to cross the street."

question: What is a crosswalk?
options: "a: Another name for a four-way intersection., b: An area designated for road construction workers., c: The area where pedestrians may cross the roadway."
note: "A crosswalk is the part of the road set aside for pedestrians to safely cross the road. They are often marked with white lines. School crossings may have yellow crosswalk lines. Not all crosswalks are marked. Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks."

question: When should drivers yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in a crosswalk?
options: "a: Only if the pedestrians first wave to the driver., b: Only if the pedestrians are not texting while walking., c: At all times."
note: "Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks.  'Not all crosswalks are marked. Pedestrians have the right-of-way in marked or unmarked crosswalks.'"

question: You are driving on the freeway. The vehicle in front of you is a large truck. You should drive
options: "a: Closely behind the truck in bad weather because the driver can see farther ahead, b: Farther behind the truck than you would a passenger vehicle to be out of the truck drivers blind spot, c: No more than one car length behind the truck, d: None of the above"
note: "Farther behind the truck than you would a passenger vehicle to be out of the truck drivers blind spot'. This is emphasized in the 'Blind Spots (The No Zone)' section of The DMV handbook on page 42: 'If you cannot see the truck's side mirrors, the truck driver cannot see you.'"

question: A safety zone is a specially marked area for passengers to get on or off buses or trolleys. You may not drive through a safety zone:
options: "a: Only when a bus or trolley is present., b: Only when a bus or trolley is unloading passengers., c: At any time or for any reason."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'Safety zones are spaces set aside for pedestrians waiting for buses, streetcars, and trolleys. Safety zones are marked by raised buttons or markers on a road. Do not drive through a safety zone under any condition.'"

question: "No zones" are areas around trucks where cars:
options: "a: Disappear into blind spots or are so close that they restrict the truck driver's ability to stop and maneuver safely., b: Have sufficient space to travel behind the truck., c: Have several car lengths between their vehicle and the truck."
note: "The correct answer is 'a'.  The DMV handbook states that  'Large vehicle and truck drivers have a better view in front of them and bigger mirrors. But they also have large blind spots, also called No Zones. In these areas, your vehicle can disappear from a large vehicle or truck driver's view.'  (Page 42)"

question: Extra space in front of a large truck is needed for:
options: "a: Other drivers to merge onto the freeway., b: The truck driver to stop the vehicle., c: Other drivers when they want to slow down."
note: "The correct answer is (b). 'Large vehicles and commercial trucks take longer to stop than passenger vehicles traveling at the same speed. When traveling, they create extra space in front of their vehicle to use if they need to stop suddenly.'"

question: If you are driving near a large commercial vehicle, you should:
options: "a: Follow the large vehicle closely to reduce wind drag on your vehicle., b: Avoid driving beside it for long stretches of time., c: Drive on its right side when on curves and hills."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you should 'Always pass a large vehicle on the left side. After you pass the large vehicle or truck, move ahead of it. Driving alongside a large vehicle makes it hard for the driver to avoid dangers in the road.'"

question: Increase your following distance when driving behind a large vehicle:
options: "a: To better see around the sides of the vehicle., b: Because other drivers tend to pull behind large vehicles before trying to pass them., c: Because following too closely will get you caught in the vehicle's slipstream."
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 42: 'Tailgating decreases a vehicle's safety distance.'"

question: Large trucks turning onto a street with two lanes in each direction:
options: "a: May complete the turn in either of the two lanes., b: Often have to use the left lane to complete the turn., c: Must stay in the right lane at all times while turning."
note: "The correct answer is **b**, 'Often have to use the left lane to complete the turn.'  The DMV Handbook states on page 42: 'When a vehicle turns, the rear wheels follow a shorter path than the front wheels. The longer the vehicle, the greater the difference in the length of the turning path. This is why large vehicles and truck drivers must often swing wide to complete a turn.'"

question: Stopping distances and severity of crashes:
options: "a: Decrease as vehicle speed increases., b: Are not affected by vehicle speed., c: Increase as vehicle speed increases."
note: "The DMV handbook states: 'The heavier the vehicle and the faster it is moving, the longer it takes to safely stop, so a loaded truck will take longer to stop than an empty truck.'"

question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
options: "a: They are eliminated if you have one outside mirror on each side of the vehicle., b: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles., c: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirrors."
note: "The DMV handbook states that large vehicles and truck drivers have a better view in front of them and bigger mirrors, but they also have large blind spots, also called No Zones.  'In these areas, your vehicle can disappear from a large vehicle or truck driver's view. If you cannot see the truck's side mirrors, the truck driver cannot see you.'"

question: Which of these statements is true about large trucks?
options: "a: They take longer to stop than passenger vehicles., b: They all have air brakes that allow them to stop quickly., c: They are more maneuverable than passenger vehicles."
note: "Large vehicles and commercial trucks take longer to stop than passenger vehicles traveling at the same speed."

question: You should not make sudden stops in front of large trucks and buses because:
options: "a: Small vehicle drivers cannot adequately see large trucks and buses in their rearview mirrors., b: Large trucks and buses, c: Large trucks and buses travel at a higher speeds than small vehicles."
note: "Large vehicles take longer to stop than passenger vehicles traveling at the same speed.  'The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 300 feet. A large vehicle traveling at the same speed can take up to 400 feet to stop. The heavier the vehicle and the faster it is moving, the longer it takes to safely stop, so a loaded truck will take longer to stop than an empty truck. The large vehicle will not be able to stop fast enough to avoid crashing into you.'"

question: A safety zone is a specially marked area for passengers to get on or off of buses or trolleys. You may not drive through a safety zone:
options: "a: When a bus or trolley is present., b: When a bus or trolley is unloading passengers., c: At any time for any reason."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Safety zones are spaces set aside for pedestrians waiting for buses, streetcars, and trolleys.' It then goes on to say, 'Do not drive through a safety zone under any condition.'"

question: If you want to pass a pedestrian who is walking along the roadway and an oncoming vehicle is approaching, you should:
options: "a: Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass before you pass the pedestrian., b: Keep driving at a steady speed. The oncoming vehicle must stop for you., c: Honk your horn to get the pedestrian to move over."
note: "The correct answer is **a**.  The DMV handbook states that if you are on a two-lane road with an oncoming vehicle and a pedestrian, you should 'take one danger at a time'.  This means you should slow down and allow the oncoming vehicle to pass before attempting to pass the pedestrian. 'If there is a steady flow of oncoming vehicles, use as much of the left lane as you safely can to pass the bicyclist.' (Page 43)"

question: You must always look carefully for motorcycles before you change lanes or make a left turn because they
options: "a: Have the right-of-way, b: Are hard to see, c: Are driven too fast"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 44, 'Motorcycles are smaller in size and harder to see so they easily disappear in vehicle blind spots.'  Therefore, the correct answer is **b**."

question: When you hear the siren or see the red emergency light of a closely approaching ambulance, police vehicle, or fire truck, you must
options: "a: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop, b: Move in to the right lane and drive slowly until has passed, c: Speed up to clear traffic"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, page 44, you must 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: When following a motorcycle, drivers must remember that motorcycles can ____________ than other vehicles.
options: "a: Accelerate much faster, b: Stop much more quickly, c: Stop much more slowly"
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 44, 'Allow a safe three-second following distance. This space will help you avoid hitting a motorcyclist if they brake suddenly or fall.'"

question: Which statement is true about motorcyclists and motorists?
options: "a: Motorcyclists have the same rights/responsibilities as other motorists, b: Motorcyclists are heavier than other vehicles and are less affected by wind/rain, c: Motorcyclists are not allowed to drive faster than other traffic during congested road conditions"
note: "Motorcyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as other vehicle drivers. 'Motorcyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as other vehicle drivers.' - DMV Handbook, Page 44"

question: You must yield the right of way to an emergency vehicle by:
options: "a: Driving as near to the right edge of the road as possible and stopping., b: Moving into the right lane and driving slowly until it has passed., c: Stopping immediately even if you are in an intersection."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 44, 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Failure to pull over may result in a ticket. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: You are driving on a city street and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights behind you. What should you do?
options: "a: Drive to the right edge of the road and slow down., b: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop., c: Stay in your lane slow down and let it pass."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Failure to pull over may result in a ticket. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: Always carefully look for motorcycles before you change lanes because:
options: "a: Their small size can make them hard to see., b: They usually have the right-of-way at intersections., c: It is illegal for motorcycles to share traffic lanes."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Motorcycles are smaller in size and harder to see so they easily disappear in vehicle blind spots.'  This means you should be extra cautious when changing lanes as they can easily be missed."

question: Children on bicycles should be given extra space by motor vehicle operators because:
options: "a: They do not have the same physical reflexes as adults., b: They are smaller and more difficult to see than adults., c: Both of the above."
note: "The DMV handbook explains that motorcyclists are smaller and harder to see in blind spots, and they are less protected on the road. This applies to children on bikes as well. "

question: If a child is riding a bicycle near your vehicle:
options: "a: Beep your horn., b: Expect the child to be in total control of the bicycle., c: Expect the unexpected."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Road conditions can cause motorcyclists to suddenly change speed or direction.'  This applies to children riding bicycles as well.  Children may not always be paying attention or have the same skills as an adult, so expect the unexpected when a child is riding a bicycle near you."

question: It is dangerous to follow a motorcycle too closely because:
options: "a: They do not follow the same rules as motor vehicles., b: A motorcycle can stop much faster than a standard vehicle., c: They brake more slowly than motor vehicles."
note: "According to page 44, 'Allow a safe three-second following distance. This space will help you avoid hitting a motorcyclist if they brake suddenly or fall.'"

question: Motorcycles, scooters, and mopeds are not easy to see; therefore, you should:
options: "a: Slow down when driving., b: Make constant visual checks., c: Share a lane with a motorcycle."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Motorcycles are smaller in size and harder to see so they easily disappear in vehicle blind spots.' Therefore, 'Make constant visual checks.' is the correct answer. "

question: When driving on gravel or dirt roads:
options: "a: Your tires grip the road better than when you are driving on pavement., b: Your tires do not have as much traction as they do on pavement, c: Visibility is better than on pavement."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'Maintain a safe following distance. This space will help you avoid hitting a motorcyclist if they brake suddenly or fall.'"

question: You are crossing an intersection and an emergency vehicle is approaching while using its siren and flashing lights. You should:
options: "a: Stop immediately in the intersection until it passes., b: Pull to the right of the intersection and stop., c: Continue through the intersection"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.' Therefore, the correct answer is to 'Pull to the right of the intersection and stop.'"

question: You are driving on a city street and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights behind you. What should you do?
options: "a: Drive to the right edge of the road and slow down., b: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop., c: Stay in your lane"
note: "You must give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. 'Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: You must look for bicyclists in the same lanes used by motor vehicles because they:
options: "a: Must ride facing oncoming traffic., b: Illegally share lanes with motor vehicles., c: Are entitled to share the road with motor vehicles."
note: "Motorcyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as other vehicle drivers. 'Bicyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as other drivers.'"

question: You must yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and flashing lights by:
options: "a: Driving as closely to the right edge of the road as possible and stopping., b: Moving into the right lane and driving slowly until it has passed., c: Stopping immediately"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 44: 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Failure to pull over may result in a ticket. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: When you see a NEV ROUTE sign, you should watch out for
options: "a: A Nevada law enforcement officer, b: Slow-moving vehicles in the roadway, c: Animal-drawn vehicles"
note: "On page 45, the DMV Handbook states, 'Watch for slow-moving vehicles when you see these signs or markings: - NEV USE ONLY - NEV ROUTE. NEVs and LSVs reach a maximum speed of 25 mph.'"

question: An orange and red triangular sign on a vehicle always means:
options: "a: The vehicle has the right-of-way., b: Slow-moving vehicle., c: Shoulder work ahead."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 45 that 'Some slow-moving vehicles have an orange and red triangle on their back, such as road maintenance vehicles which usually travel at 25 mph or less.'"

question: Large trucks are likely to lose speed when:
options: "a: Driving up long or steep hills., b: Driving in long, c: Driving down long"
note: "Large trucks, bicycles, and some cars lose speed on long or steep hills. 'Large trucks, bicycles, and some cars lose speed on long or steep hills.'"

question: When you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights, you must:
options: "a: Maintain your speed and stay in your lane until the vehicle has passed., b: Move into the right lane and drive slowly until the vehicle has passed., c: Pull over to the curb or edge of the road and stop until the vehicle has passed."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 45, 'Give the right-of-way to any law enforcement vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren and red lights. Failure to pull over may result in a ticket. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle(s) have passed.'"

question: You see pedestrians near the road. You should:
options: "a: Sound your horn and maintain your speed., b: Speed up to clear the area quickly., c: Slow down and pass with caution."
note: "When you see animals or livestock near the road, slow down or stop and proceed when it is safe. Be sure to follow directions from the person in charge of the animals."

question: If you are driving and you see animals standing near the roadway:
options: "a: Speed up to scare them away., b: Slow down and proceed with caution., c: Quickly swerve into the next lane."
note: "If you see a sign with a picture of an animal, watch for animals on or near the road. If you see animals or livestock near the road, slow down or stop and proceed when it is safe."

question: When used on roadways, bicycles are considered:
options: "a: Hazards., b: Vehicles., c: Dangerous."
note: "Bicycles are considered 'vehicles' on roadways and share the same rights and responsibilities as other vehicles. This is clearly stated on page 46, where The DMV handbook says 'Bicyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as other drivers.'"

question: You want to pass a bicyclist riding on the right edge of your lane. You
options: "a: must honk your horn before passing the bicyclist, b: must not squeeze past the bicyclist, c: may not pass the bicyclist for any reason"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'When you cannot change lanes to pass a bicyclist, allow at least three feet between your vehicle and the bicyclist. If you cannot give three feet of space, do not pass the cyclist until three feet of clearance can be given.'"

question: When a bicyclist is making a left turn:
options: "a: They may use the left lane., b: They may cut through all lanes., c: They may wait on the side of the road."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Bicyclists may… make left and right turns in the same way drivers do, using hand signals and turn lanes.'"

question: Bicycle riders must
options: "a: Ride facing traffic when there is no bike lane, b: Be given a safe amount of space when being passed by automobile drivers, c: Never walk the bicycle across the street"
note: "The DMV handbook states that drivers must leave at least three feet of space when passing a bicyclist. 'When you cannot change lanes to pass a bicyclist, allow at least three feet between your vehicle and the bicyclist. If you cannot give three feet of space, do not pass the cyclist until three feet of clearance can be given. This will help you avoid putting the bicyclist in danger.'"

question: You want to pass a bicyclist riding on the right edge of your lane. You
options: "a: Must not squeeze past the bicyclist, b: May not pass the bicyclist for any reason, c: Must honk your horn before passing the bicyclist"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, you must leave at least three feet of space between your vehicle and the bicyclist when passing. If you cannot give three feet of space, do not pass the cyclist until three feet of clearance can be given.  This means you must not squeeze past the bicyclist."

question: You are driving behind a motorcycle and want to pass. You must:
options: "a: Stay in the right lane as much as possible because the motorcycle is small and doesn't use all of the lane., b: Blow your horn to make the motorcycle move onto the shoulder so that you can pass., c: Have your vehicle entirely in the left lane before and during the pass."
note: "To safely pass a motorcycle that is in the travel lane you may need to change to another lane. In this case, pass safely then return to your original lane. Leave space between your vehicle and the bicyclist."

question: You want to pass a bicyclist in a narrow traffic lane when an oncoming vehicle is approaching. You should:
options: "a: Honk your horn then pass the bicyclist., b: Slow down and let the vehicle pass you before you pass the bicyclist., c: Wait until the bicyclist rides off the roadway."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'When you cannot change lanes to pass a bicyclist, allow at least three feet between your vehicle and the bicyclist.'  Therefore, the best approach is to slow down and allow the oncoming vehicle to pass before attempting to pass the bicyclist."

question: If you see orange construction signs and cones on a freeway, you must
options: "a: Slow down because the road ends, b: Be prepared for workers and slow moving equipment, c: Change lanes and maintain speed"
note: "You will see warning signs and message boards when there are workers, slow-moving equipment, and closed lanes ahead.  Go through the work zone carefully by: Slowing down.  Allowing extra space between vehicles. Expecting sudden slowing or stopping.  Watching for drivers changing lanes.  Avoiding distractions."

question: If traffic light is red, but a police officer or fire fighter on duty tells you to go ahead, you should
options: "a: Wait for the green light, b: Do as he or she tells you, c: Report him or her to police"
note: "Obey any direction, order, or signal given by a law enforcement officer, or firefighter. Follow their orders even if they conflict with existing signs, signals, or laws."

question: Which sign on a truck means that the truck's load is potentially dangerous?
options: "a: Octagonal., b: Diamond shaped., c: Rectangular wide., d: None of the above"
note: "A diamond-shaped sign on a truck means that the truck's load may be dangerous (gas, explosives etc.)."

question: Drivers are required to obey instructions from:
options: "a: Security guards patrolling parking lots., b: Other drivers whose vehicles are broken down on the roadway., c: Flaggers (signal persons) at construction sites."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Obey special signs or instructions from workers such as flaggers.'"

question: Fines in a construction zone are:
options: "a: Doubled., b: Tripled., c: Cut in half."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 49, 'Fines are also doubled in highway construction or maintenance zones when workers are present.'"

question: If a traffic signal light is green and a police officer signals for you to stop, you should:
options: "a: Obey the officer., b: Obey the traffic signal., c: Do what the vehicle in front of you does."
note: "According to page 49, 'Obey any direction, order, or signal given by a law enforcement officer, or firefighter. Follow their orders even if they conflict with existing signs, signals, or laws.'"

question: If you are continually being passed on the right and the left while driving in the center lane of an expressway, you should:
options: "a: Stay in the center lane., b: Move to the lane on your right., c: Move to the lane on your left."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, on a multilane road, the passing lane is on the far left, and the right lane is used to enter or exit traffic.  The DMV handbook states that if you are driving slower than the flow of traffic, you should drive in the right lane. 'If you choose to drive slower than other traffic, drive in the right lane.' (Page 49)"

question: If you see orange construction signs and cones on a freeway, you must:
options: "a: Slow down because the lane ends ahead., b: Be prepared for workers and equipment ahead., c: Change lanes and maintain your current speed."
note: "You will see warning signs and message boards when there are workers, slow-moving equipment, and closed lanes ahead. Go through the work zone carefully by: - Slowing down. - Allowing extra space between vehicles. - Expecting sudden slowing or stopping. - Watching for drivers changing lanes. - Avoiding distractions."

question: There is a vehicle stopped on the right shoulder of the road with its hazard lights on. You should:
options: "a: Change lanes to the left and speed up., b: Slow down and pass very carefully., c: Stop your vehicle until you can see what has happened."
note: "When approaching a stationary emergency vehicle with flashing emergency signal lights (hazard lights), move over and slow down.  If you are in an intersection when you see an emergency vehicle, continue through the intersection. Drive to the right as soon as it is safe and stop."

question: When driving in a construction zone:
options: "a: Slightly increase your speed., b: Expect the unexpected., c: Expect construction workers to yield to motorists."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 49 that 'You will see warning signs and message boards when there are workers, slow-moving equipment, and closed lanes ahead.'  Thus, the answer is 'Expect the unexpected' which is synonymous with being prepared for any road conditions."

question: When driving in work zones, you should:
options: "a: Increase your speed to get through the zone as quickly as possible., b: Reduce your speed and be prepared to stop suddenly., c: Maintain your normal speed the whole way through the zone."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Go through the work zone carefully by: Slowing down., Allowing extra space between vehicles., Expecting sudden slowing or stopping.'"

question: When driving in work zones, you should:
options: "a: Follow the driver in front of you closely., b: Pass the driver in front of you as soon as you can., c: Avoid tailgating and keep a safe following distance."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 49, 'Go through the work zone carefully by: ... Allowing extra space between vehicles.'"

question: Which of the following is a dangerous habit when driving in work zones?
options: "a: Tailgating another vehicle, b: Failing to carefully watch for workers and moving equipment, c: Both of the above"
note: "Both tailgating and failing to carefully watch for workers and moving equipment are dangerous habits when driving in work zones. The DMV handbook states, 'Go through the work zone carefully by:  - Slowing down. - Allowing extra space between vehicles. - Expecting sudden slowing or stopping. - Watching for drivers changing lanes. - Avoiding distractions.'  Tailgating would violate the rule of allowing extra space between vehicles, and failing to watch for workers and equipment would violate the rule of expecting sudden slowing or stopping. "

question: Which of the following is true about vehicles displaying a diamond-shaped sign that indicates a hazardous load?
options: "a: They are not allowed to drive on freeways., b: They must stop before crossing railroad tracks., c: They are not allowed to exceed 35 mph."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 49, 'Vehicles with these signs **must** stop before crossing railroad tracks.'"

question: Which of these statements is true about roadwork zones?
options: "a: Fines are the same for violations committed in work zones as they are under normal traffic conditions., b: You must ‘Slow for the Cone Zone’, c: Slow down only if you think workers are present."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that drivers should 'Slow for the Cone Zone.' (page 49)"

question: Work zone barriers, drums, cones, and signs are used to:
options: "a: Make drivers angry about slow traffic., b: Inconvenience drivers., c: Keep traffic out of hazardous work zones."
note: "Cones, drums, and barriers are used to keep traffic out of a hazardous work zone. 'Go through the work zone carefully by: Slowing down.' 'Cones, drums, or other barriers will guide you through the work zone.' "

question: You see a signal person at a road construction site ahead. You should obey his or her instructions:
options: "a: Only if you see orange cones on the road ahead., b: Unless they conflict with existing signs, c: At all times."
note: "On page 49, it is stated that 'Obey special signs or instructions from workers such as flaggers.'"

question: What should you do when there is a school bus ahead that starts flashing yellow warning lights?
options: "a: Slow down and prepare to stop., b: Stop immediately and remain stopped., c: Cautiously pass the school bus on the left."
note: "When a school bus flashes yellow lights, you must slow down and prepare to stop. 'Some school buses flash yellow lights when preparing to stop to let children off the bus. The yellow flashing lights warn you to slow down and prepare to stop.'"

question: When is it required for you to obey directions from a crossing guard?
options: "a: At all times., b: During school hours only., c: Only when children are present in front of a school."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you should 'Be sure to obey their directions at all times.' when referring to school safety patrols or crossing guards."

question: You are passing a school and see children near the street. You may not drive faster than
note: "The DMV handbook states 'The speed limit is 25 mph within 500 feet of a school while children are outside or crossing the street.'"

question: Driving so slowly as to interfere with normal or reasonable flow of traffic, except when necessary for safety, is
options: "a: A violation of the law, b: The right of any driver, c: Legal but not advisable"
note: "The DMV Handbook states: 'You must drive slower when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. At the same time, you should not block normal and reasonable traffic flow by driving too slowly. If you drive faster or slower than the speed limit, you may be cited.'"

question: Driving slowly in front of traffic in the far left (last) lane on any freeway
options: "a: Cannot result in a traffic citation, b: Saves lives by causing others to slow down too, c: Can frustrate other drivers and make them angry"
note: "While driving slowly on the freeway in the far left lane might not be illegal, it can 'frustrate other drivers and make them angry'. It can also block normal and reasonable traffic flow. 'If you drive faster or slower than the speed limit, you may be cited.'  (Page 50)"

question: Should you always drive slower than other traffic?
options: "a: No you can block traffic when you drive too slowly., b: Yes it is a good defensive driving technique., c: Yes it is always safer than driving faster."
note: "The DMV handbook states that while you should drive slower in heavy traffic or bad weather, you should not block traffic by driving too slowly. 'At the same time, you should not block normal and reasonable traffic flow by driving too slowly.'"

question: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and signal arm extended, you should:
options: "a: Stop., b: Proceed at 15 mph if no children are present., c: Proceed at normal speed"
note: "When a school bus flashes red lights (located at the top, front, and back of the bus), you must stop from either direction until the children are safely across the street and the lights stop flashing. Remain stopped while the red lights are flashing. If you fail to stop, you may be fined up to $1,000 and your driving privilege could be suspended for one year."

question: If you drive more slowly than the flow of traffic, you will most likely:
options: "a: Interfere with traffic and receive a ticket., b: Improve traffic flow., c: Demonstrate defensive driving techniques."
note: "The DMV Handbook states, '...you should not block normal and reasonable traffic flow by driving too slowly.'  'If you drive faster or slower than the speed limit, you may be cited.' (Page 50)"

question: If you pass a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing, you will:
options: "a: Be fined up to $1000, b: Be fined up to $100., c: Face no legal consequences."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, on page 50, 'If you fail to stop, you may be fined up to $1,000 and your driving privilege could be suspended for one year.'"

question: In traffic moving at 50 to 55 mph, you are least likely to have an accident if you:
options: "a: Drive a few miles per hour faster than most other vehicles., b: Stay within that speed range., c: Drive a few miles per hour slower than most other vehicles."
note: "The DMV handbook emphasizes the importance of maintaining a safe speed that is appropriate for the current road conditions.  It specifically advises against driving faster or slower than the flow of traffic, which can lead to increased risk of accidents. The DMV handbook states, 'If you drive faster or slower than the speed limit, you may be cited.'  Therefore, staying within the speed range of 50 to 55 mph is the safest choice."

question: The speed limit on a school zone where children are present is ____, unless otherwise posted.
options: "a: 15 mph, b: 25 mph, c: 20 mph"
note: "According to page 50, the speed limit within 500 feet of a school while children are outside or crossing the street is 25 mph, unless otherwise posted."

question: There are two traffic lanes moving in your direction. You are driving in the left lane and many vehicles are passing you on the right. If the driver behind you wishes to drive faster, you should:
options: "a: Stay in your lane so you don't impede the flow of traffic., b: Drive onto the left shoulder to let the other vehicles pass., c: Move into the right lane when it is safe."
note: "The DMV handbook states: 'If you choose to drive slower than other traffic, drive in the right lane.'  This indicates that if you are being passed in the left lane, you should move to the right lane to allow faster vehicles to pass."

question: Vehicles stopped behind a school bus with its red lights flashing must remain stopped until:
options: "a: All students are off the bus., b: The stop arm is retracted., c: The stop arm is retracted and the bus resumes motion."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 50, 'When the bus flashes red lights (located at the top, front, and back of the bus), you must stop from either direction until the children are safely across the street and the lights stop flashing. Remain stopped while the red lights are flashing.'"

question: When a school bus is picking up or dropping off children, you must:
options: "a: Stop, b: Stop if you are driving in the same direction., c: Slow down and be prepared to stop."
note: "The correct answer is 'a'.  The DMV handbook states on page 50, 'All vehicles must stop for school buses. When the bus flashes red lights (located at the top, front, and back of the bus), you must stop from either direction until the children are safely across the street and the lights stop flashing. Remain stopped while the red lights are flashing.'"

question: When a school bus is stopped ahead on your side of the road with its red lights flashing, you must:
options: "a: Slow to a speed no faster than 10 mph., b: Stop until the lights stop flashing., c: Change lanes and pass cautiously."
note: "When the bus flashes red lights (located at the top, front, and back of the bus), you must stop from either direction until the children are safely across the street and the lights stop flashing. Remain stopped while the red lights are flashing."

question: When a school bus is stopped on the road ahead to load or unload children, you must:
options: "a: Come to a complete stop until all the children have left the bus., b: Come to a complete stop until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm is withdrawn., c: Change lanes"
note: "The DMV Handbook states that when a school bus is stopped with its red lights flashing and stop arm extended, you must come to a complete stop. This is to ensure the safety of children loading or unloading the bus."

question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: "a: Driving too slowly is not an unsafe practice., b: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous., c: The speed at which you drive a vehicle does not affect safety."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'You must drive slower when there is heavy traffic or bad weather. At the same time, you should not block normal and reasonable traffic flow by driving too slowly. If you drive faster or slower than the speed limit, you may be cited.'"

question: Which of these vehicles must always stop before crossing railroad tracks?
options: "a: Tank trucks marked with hazardous materials placards., b: Motor homes or pickup trucks towing a boat trailer., c: Any vehicle with three or more axles and weighing more than 4"
note: "Vehicles with hazardous materials placards must always stop before crossing railroad tracks.  This is stated on page 50 of the DMV handbook."

question: What should you do when traffic is slow and heavy, and you must cross railroad tracks before reaching the upcoming intersection?
options: "a: Begin crossing when the vehicle in front of you is crossing the tracks., b: Wait on the tracks until the stoplight at the intersection turns green., c: Wait until you can completely cross the tracks before proceeding."
note: "You must wait until you can completely cross the railroad tracks before proceeding. 'Never stop on the railroad tracks. Wait and do not begin proceeding if you do not have enough room to completely cross the tracks. If you are on the tracks, you risk injury or death.'"

question: When you approach a 'blind' intersection (you can't see 100 feet down the cross street) and there is no STOP or YIELD sign placed at the corner, the speed limit is
note: "The DMV Handbook states that the speed limit is 15 mph within 100 feet of a railroad crossing and you cannot see the tracks for 400 feet in both directions.  This applies to intersections as well.  The speed limit is 15 mph for a blind intersection if your view is blocked, move slowly forward until you can see."

question: You must stop at the intersection ahead. Just before the intersection, you have to cross railroad tracks. You should stop before you cross the railroad tracks when
options: "a: You don’t have room to completely cross the tracks, b: The crossing is located in a city or town with frequent train traffic, c: You transport two or more children in a passenger vehicle"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'Never stop on the railroad tracks. Wait and do not begin proceeding if you do not have enough room to completely cross the tracks. If you are on the tracks, you risk injury or death.'"

question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in a business district is
options: "a: 35 MPH, b: 30 MPH, c: 25 MPH"
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'The speed limit is 25 mph, unless otherwise posted.'  This statement can be found on page 51."

question: The speed limit in any alley is
options: "a: 25 MPH, b: 20 MPH, c: 15 MPH"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 51: 'The speed limit in an alley is 15 mph.'"

question: Always stop before crossing railroad tracks when:
options: "a: There isn't room on the other side for you to completely cross the tracks., b: The railroad crossing is located in a city or town that has frequent train traffic., c: You are transporting two or more young children in a passenger vehicle."
note: "According to page 51, 'Never stop on the railroad tracks. Wait and do not begin proceeding if you do not have enough room to completely cross the tracks. If you are on the tracks, you risk injury or death.'"

question: At a railroad crossing, you must:
options: "a: Watch for vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings (school buses), b: Watch for multiple trains., c: Both of the above."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you must 'Expect a train on any track, at any time, traveling in either direction.' and  'Watch for vehicles that must stop before they cross train tracks. These vehicles include buses, school buses, and vehicles marked with a hazardous materials placard.'"

question: At an uncontrolled intersection where you cannot see cross traffic until you are just about to enter the intersection, the speed limit is:
options: "a: 15 mph., b: 25 mph., c: 20 mph."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'An intersection is considered blind if it has no stop signs at any corner. If your view is blocked, move slowly forward until you can see. The speed limit for a blind intersection is 15 mph.'"

question: If you come to a railroad crossing with lowered gates and flashing warning lights, you should:
options: "a: Drive around the crossing gates if you can't see a train., b: Come to a complete stop well behind the gates, c: Slow down and drive around the gates."
note: "When the crossing devices or a person warns you a train is coming, stop at least 15 feet from the nearest track."

question: If you come to an intersection and your view to the side is blocked, you should:
options: "a: Slow down and look both ways., b: Maintain your speed and look both ways., c: Stop"
note: "The DMV handbook states that if your view is blocked, you should 'move slowly forward until you can see.'  The speed limit for a blind intersection is 15 mph.  Option 'a' best represents the need to slow down and carefully check for traffic in all directions."

question: The speed limit in any alley is:
options: "a: 20 mph., b: 15 mph., c: 25 mph."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'The speed limit in an alley is 15 mph.'"

question: When crossing a sidewalk to enter traffic from an alley or driveway, drivers should:
options: "a: Stop only if pedestrians are on the sidewalk., b: Stop before driving onto the sidewalk or sidewalk area., c: Expect pedestrians on the sidewalk to yield the right-of-way."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You may drive on or cross a sidewalk to enter or exit a driveway or alley.'  This means drivers should stop before driving onto the sidewalk or sidewalk area."

question: When may you legally drive around or under a railroad crossing gate?
options: "a: Never., b: When you can see clearly in both directions., c: When the warning lights are not flashing."
note: "According to page 51, 'Do not go under lowering gates or around lowered gates.'"

question: Which statement is true?
options: "a: You should put on your cruise control near a railroad crossing to maintain a constant speed., b: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign., c: You have the right-of-way at a railroad crossing and do not need to stop."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'When the crossing devices or a person warns you a train is coming, stop at least 15 feet from the nearest track.' This indicates that you must stop when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Option 'a' is incorrect because using cruise control at a railroad crossing is not recommended as it may not allow for quick stopping in case of an approaching train. Option 'c' is incorrect because drivers must stop at railroad crossings when directed to do so."

question: You are approaching a railroad crossing with no warning devices and are unable to see 400 feet down the tracks in one direction. The speed limit is:
options: "a: 15 mph., b: 20 mph., c: 25 mph."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'The speed limit is 15 mph within 100 feet of a railroad crossing and you cannot see the tracks for 400 feet in both directions.'"

question: You have stopped for a train at a railroad crossing. After the train passes, you should:
options: "a: Wait for signal lights to stop flashing., b: Look for a second train., c: Both of the above."
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 51 that, 'When the crossing devices or a person warns you a train is coming, stop at least 15 feet from the nearest track.' The DMV handbook also states that, 'Do not proceed over the railroad tracks until the red lights stop flashing, even if the gate rises.'"

question: You must stop at the intersection ahead. Just before the intersection, you have to cross railroad tracks. You should stop before crossing the railroad tracks when:
options: "a: There isn't room on the other side for you to completely cross the tracks., b: The crossing is located in a city or town with frequent train traffic., c: You are transporting two or more children in a passenger vehicle."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 51, 'Never stop on the railroad tracks. Wait and do not begin proceeding if you do not have enough room to completely cross the tracks. If you are on the tracks, you risk injury or death.'"

question: A passenger vehicle may NOT tow
options: "a: One trailer, b: Another passenger vehicle, c: Two trailers"
note: "The DMV Handbook states on page 52, 'You must drive in the far-right lane or a lane marked for slower vehicles when you: … Tow a vehicle or trailer.' It also states, 'You cannot carry anything in or on a passenger vehicle which extends beyond the fenders on the left side or more than 6-inches beyond the fenders on the right side.'"

question: The speed limit in a residential area is
options: "a: 10 mph, b: 25 mph, c: 30 mph"
note: "The DMV handbook states that the speed limit is 25 mph in business or residential districts unless otherwise posted. 'The speed limit is 25 mph, unless otherwise posted.'"

question: A person may legally ride in the back of a pickup truck when:
options: "a: The sides of the pickup bed are at least 24 inches high., b: The back of the pickup is covered with a camper shell., c: In a secured seat and while using an approved safety belt."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'You must not allow a person to ride in the back of a pickup or other truck unless the vehicle has secure seats and seat (safety) belts.'"

question: Abandoning an animal on the highway may result in:
options: "a: Jail time., b: A point against your license., c: No legal consequences."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You must **not** dump or abandon animals on a highway. This crime is punishable by a fine of up to $1,000, six months in jail, or both.'"

question: Animals may be transported in the back of a pickup truck only if:
options: "a: The sides of the truck bed are at least 18 inches high., b: They are properly secured., c: The tailgate of the truck is closed."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'Not transport animals in the back of a pickup or other truck unless the animal is properly secured. This prevents the animal from falling, jumping, or being thrown from the vehicle.'"

question: Smoking inside a vehicle with a person younger than 18 years of age is:
options: "a: Legal, b: Illegal at all times., c: Not restricted by law."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'You must: Not smoke when a minor is in the vehicle. You can be fined.' This information is found on page 52."

question: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in a residential area is:
options: "a: 20 mph., b: 25 mph., c: 30 mph."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 52 'The speed limit is 25 mph, unless otherwise posted.' in the section about business or residential districts."

question: Any driver who willfully flees or attempts to evade law enforcement, during which a person is seriously injured, is subject to:
options: "a: Imprisonment in a state prison for up to seven years., b: A fine of less than $1000., c: Attending an anger-management class."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 53 that 'A person convicted of causing serious bodily injury during a law enforcement pursuit is subject to imprisonment in a state prison for up to seven years, or a county jail for one year or less.'"

question: If you are repeatedly convicted for traffic violations
options: "a: DMV may impound your vehicle, b: Your driving privilege may be suspended by DMV, c: Both of the above"
note: "The DMV book states on page 53 that 'DMV monitors your driver's record. If you are stopped by a law enforcement officer and cited (ticketed) for a traffic violation...As an adult or minor, if you get a traffic ticket and fail to appear (FTA) in court, DMV may suspend your driving privilege until you appear...As an adult, your license may be suspended if your driver's record shows one of the following point totals: 4 points in 12 months., 6 points in 24 months., 8 points in 36 months.'"

question: A person convicted of reckless driving or engaging in a speed contest that causes injury to another person is subject to
options: "a: imprisonment and a fine, b: community service, c: all the above"
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'A person convicted of reckless driving or engaging in a speed contest that causes injury to another person is subject to imprisonment, a fine, or both.'"

question: A peace officer is signaling for you to drive to the edge of the roadway. You decide to ignore the officer's warning and flee the scene. You are guilty of a misdemeanor and can be punished by being:
options: "a: Fined up to $1000, b: Jailed in the county jail for not more than one year., c: Given a warning and a citation."
note: "The correct answer is 'b.' The DMV handbook, on page 53, states: 'It is a misdemeanor to use a motor vehicle to flee or attempt to evade law enforcement performing their duties. This is punishable by imprisonment in a county jail for one year or less.'"

question: Which of these vehicles must always stop before crossing railroad tracks?
options: "a: Tank trucks with hazardous materials placards., b: Motor homes or pickup trucks towing a boat trailer., c: Sport utility vehicles carrying four or more persons."
note: "According to page 54, 'Vehicles with these signs must stop before crossing railroad tracks.'"

question: Which of the following is an example of a safe driving practice?
options: "a: Staring only at the middle of the road., b: Always keep your eyes moving to scan the surroundings., c: Using your high-beam headlights in the fog"
note: "The DMV Handbook states to 'always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle' on page 57."

question: Which of the following should you do if you are being followed by a tailgater?
options: "a: Change lanes and allow the tailgater to pass., b: Tap the brakes to signal you are moving at a slower pace., c: Increase your speed to match the speed of the vehicle."
note: "The DMV handbook recommends that you change lanes and allow the tailgater to pass when safe to do so. 'Maintain your course and speed. Then, when safe to do so, merge right to change into another lane and allow the tailgater to pass.'"

question: If you become angry or upset, you should
options: "a: Go for a drive to forget your problems, b: 'Cool off' before driving, c: Control your emotions while driving"
note: "The DMV Handbook emphasizes the importance of controlling your emotions while driving, stating: 'If you become angry or upset, you should 'cool off' before driving.'"

question: The three-second rule applies to the space ______ of your vehicle.
options: "a: To the sides, b: Ahead, c: In the back"
note: "The 'three-second rule' is a driving rule that helps you estimate how closely you should follow other vehicles. question: On a freeway, drivers should look farther ahead than they normally would on a city street
options: "a: Because it takes 500 feet to stop a vehicle on a freeway, b: In order to spot potential hazards and dangers ahead, c: Because there are multiple lanes"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle.'"

question: A driver cuts off another vehicle, or threatens another motorist or a pedestrian. These are examples of
options: "a: Excessive driving, b: Defensive driving, c: Road rage"
note: "The DMV handbook defines road rage as 'Aggressive or angry behavior by a driver, often involving a vehicle, while driving, such as cutting off another vehicle, or threatening another motorist or a pedestrian.'  It is found on page 57."

question: Tailgating
options: "a: Is a defensive driving technique, b: Cannot result in a traffic citation, c: Can frustrate other drivers and make them angry"

question: While driving, you should look 10 to 15 seconds ahead of you

question: When a hazard is seen ahead, reaction distance
options: "a: Equals total stopping distance minus perception distance, b: Is how far a vehicle will continue to travel in ideal conditions before the driver hits the brakes, c: Is the sum of perception distance and braking distance"

question: Looking down the road to where your vehicle will be in about 10 seconds helps you to
options: "a: enjoy the scenery, b: avoid last minute moves, c: see hazards inside your car"

question: To avoid last minute moves, you should be looking down the road to where your vehicle will be in about
options: "a: 5 to 10 seconds, b: 10 to 15 seconds, c: 15 to 20 seconds"
note: "The DMV handbook says 'To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle.'"

question: You are driving in the far right lane of a multi-lane street. A vehicle in the lane to your left moves into your lane causing you to slow down. You should:
options: "a: Use your horn to let the driver know they are in your lane., b: Brake hard and use your emergency flashers., c: Be prepared to adjust your speed and position to avoid a collision."

question: A driver should:
options: "a: Stare directly in front of their car., b: Only focus on the middle of the road., c: Watch beside"

question: A vehicle suddenly cuts in front of you, creating a hazard. What should you do first?
options: "a: Honk and step on the brake firmly., b: Take your foot off the gas pedal., c: Swerve into the lane next to you."
note: "The best initial reaction is to 'Take your foot off the gas pedal.' This creates space between you and the vehicle ahead, allowing you to assess the situation and react appropriately. question: Adjust your rearview and side mirrors:
options: "a: Before you start driving., b: Whenever you need to use them., c: Before you get into the car."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle.' This suggests that adjusting mirrors before starting is crucial."

question: Allow extra space in front of your vehicle when following a:
options: "a: Station wagon., b: Passenger vehicle., c: Motorcycle."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you should 'create more space in front of your vehicle when:  Following motorcyclists on metal surfaces (bridge gratings, railroad tracks, etc.), and gravel.'"

question: As your speed increases, it is important to:
options: "a: Turn on your headlights., b: Look well ahead of your vehicle., c: Change lanes frequently."
note: "To give yourself time to react, avoid last minute moves and hazards, always keep your eyes moving and scan the road at least 10 seconds ahead of your vehicle."

question: If you are being followed too closely on a two-lane road:
options: "a: Reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you., b: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the other car., c: Apply your brakes to slow down"

question: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should:
options: "a: Challenge them., b: Get out of their way., c: Speed up."

question: Interstate driving requires drivers to:
options: "a: Have the ability to safely drive at increased speeds., b: Be constantly alert., c: Both of the above."

question: What is the benefit of a space cushion around your vehicle?
options: "a: Other drivers can cut in front of you, b: If another driver makes a mistake, c: It inflates to protect you from injury in the case of a collision."
note: "A space cushion around your vehicle allows for you to react if another driver makes a mistake. The DMV Handbook states 'Following other vehicles at a safe distance gives you enough time to react if another driver makes a mistake.'"

question: When being followed by a tailgater, which of the following will help you avoid being hit from behind?

question: When driving on the highway, consistently looking far ahead of your vehicle:
options: "a: Helps you keep up with traffic., b: Reduces the need for last-minute braking or turning., c: Allows you to spot upcoming police officers."

question: When you tailgate other drivers (drive closely to their rear bumper):

question: Which of the following describes the thinking of defensive drivers?
options: "a: They know other drivers will do the right thing., b: They consider what other drivers might do and are prepared to react., c: They expect no breaks and give none."

question: While driving, you should look 10 to 15 seconds ahead of you:
options: "a: And focus on the middle of the road., b: Because it is a legal requirement., c: To see potential hazards early."

question: You can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by:

question: You drive defensively when you:

question: You should allow an extra cushion of space:
options: "a: When following a station wagon., b: When following a driver who cannot see the rear of their vehicle., c: When following a small passenger car."

question: You should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead when you:

question: To help avoid being hit from the rear by another driver when preparing to turn, you should

question: You may open your vehicle's door on the traffic side
options: "a: At any time while parked, b: To leave but not to enter your vehicle, c: Only when it is safe"

question: You see a vehicle approaching from the rear. When you check your mirror again to change lanes, you no longer see the vehicle. You should
options: "a: Turn your signal on and change lanes slowly, b: Look over your shoulder to be sure the vehicle isn’t in your blind spot, c: Check your outside mirror to see if the vehicle is in your blind spot"

question: Blind spots are:
options: "a: Spots in your vision when you become fatigued., b: Areas of the road that cannot be seen in a vehicle's mirrors., c: Traffic control devices."

question: Check your rearview mirrors:

question: Make room for cars that are entering the freeway by:

question: To see vehicles in your blind spots, you should check:

question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spot by:

question: When driving at night, you should:

question: When driving on an interstate, to avoid traffic merging from on-ramps to your right, the best thing to do is to:
options: "a: Change lanes to the left., b: Slow down., c: Maintain your speed and position."

question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, you should:

question: It is more dangerous to drive at night than during the day because:
options: "a: You cannot see as far ahead at night., b: The road is always more slippery at night., c: Your reaction time is slower at night."

question: Night driving presents unique problems because:

question: To avoid glare from the headlights of an approaching car:
