question: You are driving on a freeway with a posted speed limit of 65 mph. Traffic is heavy and moving at 35 mph. The best speed for your vehicle is most likely:
options: "a: 25 mph., b: 35 mph., c: 30 mph."
note: "The DMV handbook states that in California, you may never drive faster than is safe for the current road conditions. This is known as the Basic Speed Law. 'Make sure you manage your speed and slow down when conditions call for it. Regardless of the posted speed limit, your speed should depend on: ... The speed of other vehicles on the road.'"

question: You are driving on a freeway with a posted speed limit of 65 mph. Traffic is traveling at 70 mph. You may legally drive:
options: "a: 70 mph or faster to keep up with the speed of traffic., b: Between 65 mph and 70 mph., c: No faster than 65 mph."
note: "In California, you may never drive faster than is safe for the current road conditions. This is known as the Basic Speed Law. Make sure you manage your speed and slow down when conditions call for it. Regardless of the posted speed limit, your speed should depend on: The number of vehicles on the road. The speed of other vehicles on the road. The road surface: smooth, rough, graveled, wet, dry, wide, or narrow. Bicyclists or pedestrians on or crossing the road. Weather: rain, fog, snow, wind, or dust. Traffic congestion: small changes in your driving habits can help reduce congestion. Avoid weaving in and out of freeway lanes."

question: You should always travel:
options: "a: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you., b: At the speed limit., c: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions."
note: "You should always travel at a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.  The DMV book states, 'In California, you may never drive faster than is safe for the current road conditions. This is known as the Basic Speed Law.' "

question: What is the first thing you should do if your wheels move off the pavement?
options: "a: Ease your foot off the gas pedal and brake gently, b: Pull over to the right and sound your horn to warn the other drivers, c: Pull the steering wheel back"
note: "According to page 68, the first step you should take if your wheels drift off the pavement is to 'Grip the steering wheel firmly. Remove your foot from the accelerator. Brake gently.'"

question: If your accelerator becomes stuck you should
options: "a: Turn off the ignition while the vehicle is moving, b: Not apply the brakes. Ease off the gas pedal and straighten the front wheels, c: Shift to neutral apply the brakes and try to drive the car safely off the road"
note: "If your accelerator becomes stuck, you should 'Shift to neutral, apply the brakes, and try to drive the car safely off the road.'"

question: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, you should:
options: "a: Grip the steering wheel firmly, b: Pump the brakes rapidly., c: Brake hard and steer toward the right edge of the roadway."
note: "According to the DMV Handbook, if a tire blows out while you are driving, you should 'Hold the steering wheel with both hands. Maintain your vehicle speed if possible and safe. Gradually release the accelerator. Correct the steering as necessary to stabilize your vehicle and regain control.' "

question: If you are driving and a tire suddenly goes flat, you should:
options: "a: Rapidly pump the brake pedal several times., b: Slow down gradually and not brake., c: Press down on the brake pedal as hard as you can."
note: "When a tire blows out, suddenly braking or abruptly removing your foot from the accelerator can result in a loss of control over the vehicle. Instead, you should: 'Hold the steering wheel with both hands. Maintain your vehicle speed if possible and safe. Gradually release the accelerator. Correct the steering as necessary to stabilize your vehicle and regain control.'"

question: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, you should:
options: "a: Wait until it is safe to do so, b: Turn back onto the roadway immediately., c: Stop."
note: "If your wheels drift off the pavement, you should: 1. Grip the steering wheel firmly. 2. Remove your foot from the accelerator. 3. Brake gently. 4. Check for traffic behind you. 5. Carefully steer back onto the pavement. Do not pull or turn your steering wheel with too much force. This may cause you to drive into oncoming traffic."

question: You have allowed the wheels of your vehicle to run off the edge of the pavement. What should you do first?
options: "a: Turn the front wheels slightly to the left to edge the car back onto the pavement., b: Hold the steering wheel firmly, c: Apply the brakes and turn the front wheels sharply to the left."
note: "The first step is to 'Grip the steering wheel firmly.' This will help you maintain control of the vehicle as you steer back onto the pavement.  The DMV handbook states on page 68, 'If your wheels drift off the pavement: 1. Grip the steering wheel firmly.'"

question: If your car becomes disabled while on the highway, you should:
options: "a: Stop in the right lane., b: Park with all four wheels off the traveled highway, c: Stop where you are."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, 'If your vehicle stops working on the freeway: 1. Safely pull over to the right shoulder. 2. Exit on the right side so you are away from traffic if you must get out of the vehicle.'"

question: What should you do if your cell phone rings and you do not have a hands-free device?
options: "a: Answer the call and keep the conversation short., b: Do not answer the phone and let it go to voicemail., c: Answer the call if you are stopped at a red light."
note: "The DMV handbook states that you should 'let the call go to voicemail' if you do not have a hands-free device.  It also advises that you 'pull safely off the road' if you must return or make a call."

question: The safest precaution you can take regarding the use of cell phones and driving is
options: "a: only use your cell phone in hands free mode when necessary, b: keep your phone within easy reach so you will not need to take your eyes off the road, c: Review the number before answering the call"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Adult drivers should only use a cell phone in hands-free mode when necessary.' This suggests that hands-free mode is the safest option for using a cell phone while driving, making option 'a' the correct answer."

question: Distracted driving is:
options: "a: Anything that causes evasive action while driving., b: Anything that takes your attention away from driving., c: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving."
note: "Distracted driving is defined as anything that takes your attention away from driving. 'Avoid distractions while you drive.' (DMV handbook, page 70)"

question: If your cell phone rings while you are driving and you do not have a hands-free device, you should:
options: "a: Answer the call because it may be an emergency., b: Let the call go to voicemail., c: Check the incoming number before answering the call."
note: "The DMV handbook states 'Do not answer your cell phone if it rings. Let the call go to voicemail. If you must return or make a call, pull safely off the road.'"

question: The safest precaution that you can take when using cellular phones while driving is:
options: "a: To use hands-free devices so you can keep both hands on the steering wheel., b: To keep your phone within easy reach so you won't need to take your eyes off the road., c: To review the number before answering a call."
note: "The safest precaution is to use hands-free devices so you can keep both hands on the steering wheel.  The DMV Handbook states 'Driving while using a handheld cell phone is unsafe and illegal.'  It further recommends that adult drivers should only use a cell phone in hands-free mode when necessary."

question: Using a cell phone while operating a motor vehicle is considered a distraction because:
options: "a: It causes the driver to be concerned about the cost of the call., b: It occupies the driver's hands, c: It is an activity that draws the attention of other drivers."
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 70 'Cell phones are the main source of distracted driving. Driving while using a handheld cell phone is unsafe and illegal... It occupies the driver's hands.'"

question: When is it legal for minors to use a cell phone without a hands-free device while driving?
options: "a: When making a call while stopped at the red light, b: When making a call for emergency assistance, c: Never"
note: "According to page 70 of the California Driver's Handbook, 'It is against the law for a minor to use a cell phone or electronic wireless device to answer calls and send or respond to text messages while driving. EXCEPTION: Minors may use a cell phone to make a call for emergency assistance.'"

question: When is it legal for a person to drive with an alcoholic beverage container that has been opened?
options: "a: If the container is under the front seat., b: If the container is in the trunk of the vehicle., c: If the container is in the glove compartment."
note: "According to the DMV handbook on page 72, 'If you are carrying any alcohol, cannabis in your vehicle, the container must be sealed and unopened. If it is open, you must keep the container in the trunk or place where passengers do not sit.'"

question: Driving under the influence of any drug which makes you drive unsafely is
options: "a: Permitted if it is prescribed by a doctor, b: Against the law, c: Permitted if it is a diet pill or cold medicine"
note: "It is illegal to drive while under the influence of alcohol or any drug that affects your ability to drive safely. (page 72)"

question: It is against the law to have an open alcoholic beverage container in your vehicle, except
options: "a: On the back seat, b: In the trunk, c: In the glove compartment"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, it is illegal to have an open alcoholic beverage container in your glove box. 'It is also illegal to keep an open container of alcohol in your glove box.'  The DMV handbook also states that an open container of alcohol must be kept 'in the trunk or place where passengers do not sit.'"

question: What is a likely effect when you take another drug while you drink alcohol?
options: "a: There are no effects unless the drug is prescription only, b: If the drug is over-the-counter there are no effects, c: The effects of the alcohol and the drug are enhanced"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 72, 'It is illegal to drive after… Using any combination of alcohol or drugs that decreases your ability to drive safely.'"

question: BAC is expressed in
options: "a: Percentage of alcohol to blood, b: Ounces of alcohol in your blood, c: Percentage of blood to alcohol"
note: "The DMV handbook defines BAC as the 'amount of alcohol in your blood.'"

question: Which of these statements about drugs and driving is true?
options: "a: any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy, b: even over the counter drugs can impair your driving, c: only illegal drugs can impair your driving"

They can all affect your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.'"

question: Alcohol is:
options: "a: A stimulant., b: An antihistamine., c: A depressant."

question: Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving is permitted:
options: "a: Under no circumstances., b: If you don't feel drowsy., c: If it is prescribed by a physician."
note: "It is illegal to drive under the influence of any drug that affects your ability to drive safely. question: It is legal to drive with an alcoholic beverage container that has been opened only if the container is:
options: "a: Under the front seat., b: In the glove department., c: In the trunk."
note: "According to the DMV handbook, on page 72, 'If you are carrying any alcohol, cannabis in your vehicle, the container must be sealed and unopened. If it is open, you must keep the container in the trunk or place where passengers do not sit.'"

question: The first thing that alcohol effects is:
options: "a: Vision., b: Judgment., c: Balance."
note: "The DMV handbook states that alcohol can 'affect your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.'"

question: What is the only effective way to remove alcohol from the body?
options: "a: Drink strong coffee., b: Wait., c: Take a cold shower."
note: "The only way to remove alcohol from your system is to wait.  'As you age, your tolerance to alcohol decreases, which increases the risk of alcohol-related driving problems.'  The DMV handbook states this on page 72."

question: What is the only medically proven method of removing alcohol or other drug combinations from your system?
options: "a: Breathe in some fresh air., b: Give your body time., c: Drink coffee."
note: "The only way to remove alcohol or other drug combinations from your system is to give your body time.  The DMV handbook states that it is illegal to drive after 'drinking excessive amounts of alcohol in any form. This includes medications like cough syrup.'"

question: Which of the following driving skills are affected by the use of alcohol and/or drugs?
options: "a: Alertness and concentration., b: Reaction time and coordination., c: All of the above."
note: "The DMV handbook states that alcohol and/or drugs affect 'your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.'  This includes alertness and concentration, reaction time, and coordination."

question: Which of the following substances can affect the ability to drive?
options: "a: Tranquilizers, b: Cough syrups and cold tablets containing codeine or antihistamines., c: All of the above."
note: "The DMV Handbook clearly states 'It is illegal to drive while under the influence of alcohol or any drug that affects your ability to drive safely.' question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
options: "a: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy., b: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving., c: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'The law does not see a difference between illegal drugs and medications you get from a doctor or pharmacy. They can all affect your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.'"

question: While in a motor vehicle on a highway, it is:
options: "a: Illegal to either drink from or possess open containers of alcohol., b: Legal to drink alcohol if you're not driving., c: Legal to drink alcohol if you're driving but not drunk."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'It is illegal to drink any alcohol, to smoke or eat a cannabis product while you are driving or riding as a passenger in a vehicle.'  This means it is illegal to possess open containers of alcohol while in a motor vehicle on a highway."

question: The law states that for an adult, you are legally drunk when your blood alcohol concentration reaches a minimum of
options: "a: One hundredth (0.01) of one percent, b: One tenth (0.10) of one percent, c: Eight hundredths (0.08) of one percent"
note: "The DMV handbook states on Page 73: 'It is illegal for you to drive if you have a BAC of... 0.08% or higher if you are over 21 years old.'"

question: If you are arrested for drunk driving and refuse to submit to a chemical test of the alcohol content of your blood
options: "a: Your driving privilege will be withdrawn, b: You will receive an additional fine, c: You will not be allowed to post bail"
note: "According to the DMV handbook, if you refuse to take a blood or urine test after being suspected of driving under the influence, 'DMV will suspend or revoke your driving privilege for one year.'"

question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to operate a vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of _____ or higher.
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 73: 'It is illegal for you to drive if you have a BAC of 0.08% or higher if you are over 21 years old.'"

question: Your BAC depends on
options: "a: How much time passes between drinks, b: How much alcohol you drink, c: All of the above"
note: "Your BAC depends on all of the above: how much you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your body weight. The DMV handbook states, 'Your BAC measures how much alcohol is present in your bloodstream.'"

question: BAC is
options: "a: The acronym for Beer Accumulation, b: The number of ounces of alcohol in your blood, c: The percentage of alcohol in your blood"
note: "The DMV handbook defines BAC as 'Your BAC is the amount of alcohol in your blood.'"

question: Which of these statements is true about drinking alcohol and driving?
options: "a: If you can walk a straight line after drinking it is safe to drive., b: If you are under the legal blood alcohol concentration limit your driving isn't impaired., c: Alcohol effects judgment and self-control which are needed for driving safely."
note: "'Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit.' (page 73)"

question: A blood alcohol concentration of 0.02 percent:
options: "a: Won't have any effect on your driving., b: Won't put other drivers at risk., c: Will double your chances of having an accident."
note: "The DMV book states that 'Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit.'  While the BAC limit for driving is 0.08%, even a lower BAC can impair your judgment and increase your risk of a collision."

question: Any amount of alcohol in the blood may affect a driver's:
options: "a: Right-of-way privileges., b: Judgment and physical coordination., c: Knowledge."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit. '  This means that any amount of alcohol can impair judgment and physical coordination, making it dangerous to drive."

question: As the percentage of alcohol (BAC) in your blood increases, you become:
options: "a: More intoxicated., b: More sober., c: More coordinated."
note: "The DMV Handbook states that 'When you consume alcohol, traces of it enter your bloodstream. Your BAC measures how much alcohol is present in your bloodstream.'"

question: How many alcoholic drinks does it take to affect your driving ability?
options: "a: Three, b: Two, c: One"
note: "According to the DMV Handbook on page 73, 'Remember even one drink can affect your ability to drive safely.'"

question: If you have had several beers, the effects of alcohol will be reduced only by:
options: "a: Taking a cold shower., b: Waiting several hours., c: Drinking several cups of coffee."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit.'  It also states that 'The law does not see a difference between illegal drugs and medications you get from a doctor or pharmacy. They can all affect your ability to drive safely and react to what you see and hear.'  Therefore, the only way to reduce the effects of alcohol is to wait several hours."

question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) that is ____ or higher.
options: "a: 0.08% -- Eight-hundredths of one percent, b: 0.10% -- One-tenth of one percent, c: 0.05% -- Five-hundredths of one percent"

question: Only ____ can reduce blood alcohol content (BAC) and alcohol's effects on the body.
options: "a: Drinking caffeine, b: Eating foods high in fat, c: Time"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Only time can reduce blood alcohol content (BAC) and alcohol's effects on the body.'"

question: The amount of alcohol in the blood is referred to as:

note: "The amount of alcohol in the blood is referred to as Blood alcohol concentration (BAC).  The book states, 'Your BAC measures how much alcohol is present in your bloodstream.'"

question: Which of the following factors affect an individual's absorption of alcohol?
options: "a: Weight, b: Height, c: Intelligence"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Your BAC measures how much alcohol is present in your bloodstream.' This table shows that a person's weight is a factor that impacts alcohol absorption."

question: Which of these statements is true about drinking alcohol and driving?
options: "a: If you can walk in a straight line after drinking, b: If you are under the legal blood alcohol concentration limit, c: Alcohol affects judgement"
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'Almost everyone feels negative effects of alcohol, even at levels lower than the legal limit.' This means that even if you're under the legal BAC limit, alcohol can still affect your judgment and make you an unsafe driver."

question: Your license can be suspended if you are under 21 and drive with a blood alcohol level of:
options: "a: 0.15 percent or more., b: 0.08 percent or more., c: Any amount."
note: "The DMV handbook states, 'It is illegal for you to drive if you have a BAC of 0.01% or higher if you are under 21 years old.'"

question: If a police officer asks you to take an alcohol test, you may choose:
options: "a: A blood breath or urine test, b: A field sobriety test, c: To say the alphabet backwards"
note: "On page 74, the DMV Handbook states: 'When you drive in California, you consent to a breath, blood, or urine test if a law enforcement officer suspects you of DUI.'"

question: The 'implied consent law' says you have agreed to take a test for the alcohol content of your blood
options: "a: Whenever you drive in California, b: On advice of an attorney, c: If an accident has occurred"
note: "The DMV handbook states on page 74 'When you drive in California, you consent to a breath, blood, or urine test if a law enforcement officer suspects you of DUI.' This is the implied consent law, meaning you have agreed to take a test when driving in California."

question: If you are convicted of driving with an excessive blood alcohol concentration (BAC), you may be sentenced to serve:

"

question: You consent to take a chemical test for the alcohol content of your blood, breath, or urine:

question: Which of these is considered a common cause of collision?
options: "a: Unsafe speed, b: Not following stop signs signals and signs, c: All the above"

question: Collisions are more likely to happen when:
options: "a: All vehicles are traveling at about the same speed., b: One lane of traffic is traveling faster than the other lanes., c: One vehicle is traveling faster or slower than the flow of traffic."
note: "The DMV handbook states that 'A vehicle traveling faster or slower than the flow of traffic' is one of the most common causes of collisions. This makes option (c) the correct answer. The DMV handbook specifically mentions this on page 76, under the heading 'Causes of Collisions.'"

question: Excessive speed:
options: "a: Saves time so you can get to your destination more quickly., b: Helps you maneuver around obstacles., c: Increases the likelihood of serious bodily injury and death."

question: You are required to notify DMV by filing a Report of Traffic Accident Occurring in California (SR-1) form if:

question: You must make a financial responsibility report after an accident when damage to one of the vehicles is over $750

question: If you are involved in an accident
options: "a: Notify the local law enforcement agency or CHP if anyone is injured or killed, b: Show evidence that you have insurance only to a peace officer, c: Stop and identify yourself only if someone is injured"

question: If you are the first person to stop to give assistance at a collision scene, you should drive to the side of the road
options: "a: After you have passed the collision scene, b: Before you reach the collision scene, c: Next to the collision scene"

question: You have been involved in a minor traffic collision with a parked vehicle and you can't find the owner. You must
options: "a: Leave a note on the vehicle, b: Report the accident without delay to the city police or in unincorporated areas to the CHP, c: Both of the above"

question: If you are involved in a traffic collision and no one is injured, you are required to complete and submit a written report to

question: You must notify law enforcement and make a written report (SR1) to DMV when:

question: If you are involved in a traffic accident in California, you must file a report of the accident with the DMV when:

question: If you are involved in a traffic collision, you are required to complete and submit a written report to the DMV:

question: If you hit an animal with your vehicle while driving on a California highway, you should:

question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:

question: Which of the following are factors commonly contributing to traffic crashes?
